question: In event 8, the interviewee says the upcoming album will be simpler, rawer, and more primitive, moving back toward an old‑school direction. Which earlier discussions most plausibly drove that stylistic choice?
options: A: Event 2: He cites old‑school death metal inspirations (e.g., Sacrofago, Blasphemy, Creator, Destruction, Conqueror) and stresses hateful, aggressive lyrics in old‑school phrasing.
B: Event 6: He emphasizes that live shows are most important and albums are secondary, valuing the immediacy of touring and live performance.
C: Event 7: The interviewer references the band’s 2014 album and asks if/when new music will be heard.
D: Event 10: He says the New Zealand metal scene has died out somewhat and mentions a few band recommendations.
correct_answer: Event 2: He cites old‑school death metal inspirations (e.g., Sacrofago, Blasphemy, Creator, Destruction, Conqueror) and stresses hateful, aggressive lyrics in old‑school phrasing.
Event 6: He emphasizes that live shows are most important and albums are secondary, valuing the immediacy of touring and live performance.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (Event 8): The speaker characterizes the forthcoming album as simpler, rawer, and more primitive, aiming for an old‑school sound (audio). The visual continuity (same two men with microphones at the rustic table) confirms this is the same ongoing interview segment where he articulates this direction. Causal links: In Event 2 (audio), he details old‑school death metal inspirations and the importance of hateful, aggressive, action‑driven lyrics in an old‑school phrasing; visually he is seen speaking passionately, gesturing with the mic, reinforcing that these are his core artistic values. In Event 6 (audio), he asserts live performances matter more than albums, favoring the immediacy of touring; with the same visual setup, this underscores a performance‑first ethic. Those two earlier positions logically motivate a shift toward a simpler, rawer, more primitive sound in Event 8—one that aligns with his old‑school influences and translates powerfully in live settings. Distractors: Event 7 is merely the interviewer’s prompt about new music timing, not a driver of style; Event 10 concerns the state of the New Zealand scene, which does not dictate the band’s specific sonic direction.

question: Result sub-event (in Event 4): He says they did one rehearsal and then headed to Dubai to play the Jazz Festival. Which preceding sub-events most directly enabled him to pull this off on such short notice? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 4 – He was sent a copy of the show and immersed himself in it for a week before a single rehearsal.
B: Event 5 – He says he loves working under pressure and prefers not relying on charts.
C: Event 6 – He describes an intense prep routine (keeping charts in front of him and listening constantly while driving).
D: Event 0 – The enthusiastic introduction that calls him “the bass player’s bass player” at the Warwick booth.
gold_reasoning: Audio in Event 4 explicitly states the sequence: he was asked to take over, was sent a copy of the show, immersed himself in it for a week, then after one rehearsal they went to Dubai for the Jazz Festival. The visuals in Event 4 reinforce the live-performance context via the inset concert footage while they speak in front of a large poster of him playing bass, anchoring the discussion in onstage readiness. Audio in Event 5 adds his mindset—he loves working under pressure and doesn’t like relying on charts—explaining how he can succeed with minimal prep time; the video shows the same focused interview setup, keeping the topic on his approach. Audio in Event 6 details his intensive learning habits (charts in front of him, constant listening while driving, past rapid song-learning), which are practical methods that make a one-rehearsal turnaround feasible; visually, he gestures emphatically while discussing tools and touring, with the Warwick poster behind him signaling the professional touring context. By contrast, Event 0’s flattering introduction (visible and audible branding/intro) does not operationally enable the quick Dubai performance; it frames his reputation but is not a causal factor in accomplishing the one-rehearsal outcome.

question: Result sub-event (in Event 7): He explains his tour bass was cracked by the airline and that he kept it together with gaffer tape until repairs in Germany. Which preceding conditions most plausibly led him to choose that stopgap fix? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 7 – The airline cracked the bass’s body during travel, but the electronics still worked.
B: Event 6 – He was actively touring on a Warwick Starbass, so he needed a playable instrument immediately.
C: Event 8 – He prefers off-the-shelf instruments and will play anything acceptable, with only a minor mandolin-fret-wire modification.
D: Event 9 – He sold a $10,000 bass to John Entwistle.
gold_reasoning: In Event 7 audio, he states the airline damaged the bass’s body (it’s “all cracked”) while the electronics still worked, and he “gaffer taped” it—this direct physical cause makes a tape fix logical. Visually in Event 7, he gestures toward the poster of his bass at the booth, grounding which instrument is being discussed. In Event 6 audio, he says he is currently touring on a Warwick Starbass and details intense prep and touring context; visually the interview setting and prominent Warwick poster underscore that this is his active tour instrument. Being mid‑tour creates urgency to keep the bass playable immediately, motivating a quick tape repair. In Event 8 audio, he explains he favors off‑the‑shelf instruments and will play anything that isn’t horrible, with only small mods (mandolin fret wire). This pragmatic philosophy makes a taped, good‑enough solution acceptable. The visuals continue to show the music‑gear trade show environment, reinforcing the gear context. Event 9’s anecdote about selling a $10,000 bass is unrelated to the decision to tape and play through damage; it does not causally influence the stopgap repair choice.

question: In event 11, the video shows a close-up of Andre Bright’s business card while he recites office phone numbers, followed by a property presentations slate. Which earlier events/sub-events most directly caused the video to culminate with displaying and announcing Andre’s contact details? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 1: The host introduces Andre as the fastest solicitor in North Wales and invites him to answer buyers’/sellers’ questions in the office interview.
B: Event 2: Andre begins giving substantive guidance by explaining the 6–8 week timeline and stressing early instruction/preparation.
C: Event 9: Andre reassures viewers about fixed-fee conveyancing and encourages frequent contact (often by email), reducing fear of calling.
D: Event 0: The branding cutaway showing the “andy the estate agent” logo during the rainy street intro.
gold_reasoning: The causal chain builds across the interview before culminating in event 11’s on-screen contact reveal. Audio in event 1 frames Andre as an expert (“fastest solicitor in North Wales”) and explicitly sets up the Q&A, while the visuals confirm the professional office with ALWEN(A) JONES & BRIGHT signage. Event 2 continues the expert advisory segment, with audio detailing timelines and early preparation, visually anchored in the same office setting, reinforcing Andre’s authority and the informational nature of the video. Event 9’s audio addresses misconceptions (fear of calling due to cost), clarifies fixed-fee conveyancing, and actively encourages communication (often by email), which primes a call-to-action to contact the solicitor. These steps make it natural for event 11 to show a close-up of Andre’s business card and include him reciting phone numbers. In contrast, the logo cutaway in event 0 is general branding from the intro and does not directly motivate the later decision to display contact details. Both audio (expert setup, advice, encouragement to contact) and visuals (consistent office signage and the final business card close-up) are required to see how the interview logically leads to the contact display.

question: Result sub-event: In event 10, a female narrator concludes by introducing “open foresight” as an open-source methodology for collaboratively building visions of our complex world. Which prior event(s) most plausibly caused or directly contributed to this concluding emphasis, based on both what is shown on screen and what is said earlier in the documentary? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 8: The sequence that visually shows a world map made of the word “facebook,” a gavel striking followed by the words “BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING,” and a sign hinting at cost/value, while a female narrator lists controversies (competition with Google Plus, credit experimentation, lawsuits over address book data, government surveillance, and IPO preparation).

B: Event 9: The visuals emphasizing scale and power — “$100,000,000,000,” rows of figures labeled “ONE BILLION,” and a head silhouette opening with a question mark and the words “intentions & impact” — paired with a male narrator urging the public to question Facebook’s intentions and impact.

C: Event 1: The blue title card declaring “Facebook will become the DASHBOARD for life,” followed by speakers describing how people would ‘search there,’ ‘buy there,’ and manage relationships — signaling Facebook’s role as a centralized life platform.
D: Event 2: The prediction that youth culture will defect to other apps, find Facebook exhausting, and see it as the establishment, accompanied by reflective background music.
gold_reasoning: To infer why event 10 culminates in a call for an open, collaborative foresight method, one must synthesize both the imagery and narration across earlier segments. In event 8, the visuals (world map made of “facebook,” the gavel, and the bold “BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING”) visually foreground global reach, legal/regulatory pressure, and surveillance concerns, while the female narrator explicitly enumerates controversies (competition, credit experiments, lawsuits, surveillance, IPO). This dual visual-audio pairing sets up the need for a systematic, participatory way to grapple with Facebook’s complex trajectory. Event 9 then intensifies this by visually quantifying Facebook’s scale and influence (“$100,000,000,000,” “ONE BILLION,” and the head silhouette with a question mark labeled “intentions & impact”), while the male narrator urges the public to question intentions and impacts — a direct audio prompt for collective, reflective analysis. Event 1’s blue card (“dashboard for life”) and the speakers’ audio about centralizing searching, buying, and relationship management establish how deeply Facebook could permeate daily life, raising the stakes for thoughtful, collaborative planning. Together, these prior visual and audio cues (events 8, 9, and 1) plausibly drive the documentary to end with the open foresight methodology in event 10. By contrast, event 2’s youth-defection prediction does not directly motivate the specific methodological turn to open foresight.

question: At the start of event 10, the interviewer (woman in maroon) asserts that “a fair and equal information society will only be achieved through collaboration.” Which earlier sub-events most directly set up or prompted this collaboration-focused statement? Choose all that apply.

gold_reasoning: Audio in event 7 has the male interviewee explicitly arguing for inclusivity—"include everybody" and accommodate diversification—which frames collaboration as necessary; visually, he is the one speaking (blue traditional outfit), reinforcing speaker identity. In event 8 (audio), he praises the forum for keeping everyone "on the platform" and calls it a good opportunity for all, again foregrounding collective participation; the video keeps the same WSIS-SDG Matrix backdrop and shows him gesturing, tying the message to the ongoing discussion. In event 9, the audio captures the interviewer (female voice) explicitly remarking on the WSIS Forum and its collaboration—this is the immediate conversational pivot to collaboration, affirmed by the interviewee. The visuals in events 9–10 confirm turn-taking: we see the woman in maroon preparing to speak and then speaking in event 10, where she states that a fair and equal information society requires collaboration. Together, these three earlier sub-events (7, 8, 9) build and cue the collaboration theme that culminates in her explicit assertion in event 10. Event 3, while thematically related to broader challenges (5G, AI, jobs), does not directly foreground collaboration and thus is not the primary cause for her collaboration-focused statement.

question: In event 16, the band says they plan each gig separately and have lots of ideas for future shows, and the interviewer praises this as “commitment.” Which earlier sub-events most directly caused this meticulous, show-by-show planning approach? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 15 – They explain that because they don’t tour often, they always want to bring something extra to their shows—extra performers or other surprises—so long trips are “bring it all” occasions.
B: Event 1 – They note 2018 was full of gigs but now they’re going back to the studio, and that this year’s on-stage appearances are rare, prompting a focus on making the few gigs count.
C: Event 13 – They mention there may be a few live surprises yet to be announced but that they will be few this year, expressed with some sadness.
D: Event 14 – They talk about loving being on stage and past European/Scandinavian touring, emphasizing a desire to create more music even if only for themselves.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 16’s audio states they plan each gig separately and have lots of ideas for future gigs; the interviewer labels this “commitment,” and they exchange thanks. Visually, we see the same three men with microphones in the cluttered backstage area (boxes, posters like Wacken signage), making clear this is still about their live-performance approach. Causal chain: Event 15 (audio) provides the operational motive—since they don’t tour often, they aim to bring something extra (additional performers or surprises) when they do play. The visuals again show the same backstage interview aesthetic, reinforcing that these are their show-planning practices, not abstract ideas. Event 1 (audio) adds that after a busy 2018 of gigs they’re heading back to the studio and that on-stage appearances this year are rare. Visually, the same intimate interview setting with wall signage (“WACHEM REISEN”/posters) anchors the continuity. Fewer appearances raise the stakes of each performance, encouraging individualized planning. Event 13 (audio) further narrows expectations: only a few live surprises this year, said with some sadness, implying scarcity and selectivity. The consistent backstage visuals with boxes and posters tie this to live show logistics. These three earlier points (15’s “bring extra,” 1’s “rare appearances,” 13’s “few surprises”) directly lead to Event 16’s outcome of planning each gig separately with many ideas to maximize impact. Event 14, while thematically related (love of performing and touring), doesn’t specifically motivate individualized planning or constraints; it lacks the scarcity/extra-effort reasoning that the other events provide. Hence A, B, and C are the primary causes.

question: Result sub-event: In event 11, the principal states that the sports ground will not be touched and that they are asking the government for a big hostel and classroom complex to accommodate new courses. Which prior events/sub-events most directly led to this decision and clarification?

gold_reasoning: To understand why, in event 11, the principal declares that the sports ground will remain untouched while requesting a large hostel and classroom complex, we need both audio and visual continuity across the interview segments. Audio in event 3 adds the plan to secure hostel facilities for both UG and PG and a request for a hostel for about 3,000 students—this clearly increases accommodation needs. In event 10, the audio captures the interviewer probing whether the grounds would be used for new infrastructure and a terse “No,” which sets up the explicit clarification in event 11’s audio: the sports ground will not be touched; instead, they’ll seek a big hostel and classroom complex to handle new courses and capacity. The visual consistency across these events is necessary to confirm it’s the same principal making a connected set of decisions, while the audio provides the specific causal content. Event 8 about Darbar Hall’s museum plan is unrelated to classroom/hostel capacity and thus not causal.

question: In event 10, the speaker asserts that characters in his story "don't get lost" and that he often starts with a name that then produces the story. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly contributed to (i.e., directly set up) this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: The speaker explains that for a complicated story you must "work toward a map," tracking things like moons and suns, and describes revising extensively to keep the world consistent.
B: Event 9: A speaker highlights as a strength of the book the "enormous conglomeration of names," implying importance of naming throughout the work.
C: Event 3: While the Middle-earth map is visually foregrounded, the philologist defends the linguistic grounding of his work, emphasizing there is "quite a lot of linguistic wisdom."
D: Event 4: The speaker reminisces about early childhood memories (Warwickshire countryside, grandmother’s house, bathing in the Indian Ocean), with forest-themed visuals and book covers.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 10 (audio), the speaker claims his characters "don't get lost" and describes a method of beginning with a name that then generates the story, also noting Welsh influence on place names. The strongest causes span multiple earlier events and require both audio and visual cues. From event 2 (audio), he says that with a complicated story one must "work toward a map" and track celestial details; this provides a procedural cause for characters not getting lost (A). Event 3 (visual) repeatedly centers a Middle-earth map behind Tolkien, while the audio defends his work’s "linguistic wisdom"; this pairing visually and verbally grounds the idea that language and mapping underpin narrative clarity (C). Event 9 (audio) explicitly praises the "enormous conglomeration of names," reinforcing the importance of naming as a generative force for story (B). Together, these three events establish the methodological and linguistic foundations that lead to the event 10 outcome. Event 4 (audio/visual) concerns personal childhood memories and environment; while thematically related to inspiration, it does not directly cause the mapping-and-naming method asserted in event 10, so D is not correct.

question: In event 18, the male speaker concludes “that’s where the money is,” referring to graphene in composites over surface coatings. Which earlier discussions most directly built the causal case for this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 17 — Dr. Flint lists top real applications (membranes, surface coatings like screens/windows, and composites), setting up the surfaces vs. bulk composites comparison.
B: Event 7 — He explains that putting graphene into ceramics, metals, or plastics augments their strength, implying composites would consume significant graphene by volume.
C: Event 9 — He explains graphene membranes are only a few molecules thick, reducing pressure/energy needs and implying coatings/membranes use very little graphene per unit area.
D: Event 3 — He debunks the myth about fighter jets using graphene coatings for stealth and says the military doesn’t use them.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 18 (audio), the male speaker finishes a volume-based contrast saying a ton of graphene could coat most glass (monolayer) but only makes ~100 tons of plastic at 1%, concluding “that’s where the money is,” i.e., composites. The visual in 18 shows the same man in front of the red-and-white “i” logo, linking continuity with prior segments. Causal chain requires: (A) Event 17 (audio) enumerates practical applications—membranes, surface coatings (e.g., screens/windows), and composites—framing the surfaces vs. bulk composites comparison. Visually, the lower-third identifies him as DR. IAN FLINT, anchoring who is making the claims. (B) Event 7 (audio) explains that adding graphene into ceramics/metals/plastics makes materials significantly stronger, which is a rationale for why composites would demand more graphene by volume than ultrathin coatings. Visual continuity (same set, microphone, logo) ties this to the same speaker and topic. (C) Event 9 (audio) states graphene membranes are “only a few molecules thick,” requiring far less pressure and energy—implicitly indicating surfaces/coatings use minimal graphene per area. Visually, we see the same interview setting alternating between speakers, clarifying who provides which technical point. Together, A+B+C establish the volume contrast that culminates in event 18’s conclusion about where the market volume (and revenue) is. (D) Event 3 is about debunking military stealth myths; while it mentions coatings contextually, it does not provide the volume or application logic that leads to the composites market conclusion, so it’s not a causal contributor.

(3) Event 9 (audio and on-screen Spanish subtitles) warns that human RFI from phones/TV/satellites contaminates observations; the speaker’s emphasis and visuals of her explaining RFI make clear the need for robust discriminants. Together, these lead directly to event 10’s requirement that the candidate be a repeating narrowband signal from space—repeatability helps eliminate transient terrestrial RFI and confirm a genuine extraterrestrial origin within the radio band expected from event 7 and characterized in event 8. options: A: Event 15: The Las Vegas Aces are already blowing out the Mystics (81–47 at the end of the 3rd) with energetic play-by-play and lively game sounds, indicating strong momentum heading into later segments.
B: Event 0: The opening studio voiceover asserts the WNBA is the most competitive league, with a general montage that sets a thematic tone about competitiveness.
C: Event 6: Commentary about Candace Parker deflecting injury questions during a Sparks–Mercury game, with no Aces involvement.
D: Event 11: Early Aces home-court scene where the red team leads 15–6 in the 1st quarter with crowd energy, establishing an early cushion.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 16): Visually, the Aces’ scoreboard keeps climbing (up through the 90s), and on audio a male voice quotes a player: "I didn't come to play just to have fun. I want to win!" This pairing shows both an assertive mindset (audio) and a sustained lead (visual). The most direct contributors appear in earlier Aces segments. In event 15, the visuals show the Aces annihilating the Mystics 81–47 by the end of the third, while upbeat commentary and game sounds convey momentum and control—this context makes the later win-focused quote feel like the natural extension of their dominance (audio+visual). In event 11, visuals on the Aces floor show an early 15–6 lead and a charged arena, establishing they set the tone from the start; the whistle and courtside ambience situate it firmly in-game (audio+visual). By contrast, event 0 is a broad thematic claim about WNBA competitiveness (audio+visual) but not a specific causal game moment for the Aces’ later lead, and event 6 focuses on Candace Parker’s injury talk in a Sparks–Mercury matchup, unrelated to the Aces. Therefore, A and D are the primary causal contributors across events, supported by both the earlier visual scorelines and the energized commentary that pave the way for the event 16 result.

question: At the end of the Brittney Griner segment (event 7), a male voice concludes, "teach each other some things and passing is definitely one of them." Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led to that conclusion about passing?
options: A: Event 5: During a live sequence the commentator notes confusion on a pass after multiple misses, with Alexis Jones finally coming out of the pack with the ball—highlighting breakdowns that suggest passing needs work.
B: Event 8: The announcer calls out "inbound stolen" and a "terrible pass," along with transition pressure—clear examples of passing issues being punished.

C: Event 2: In the All-Star context, commentators note defense and say "teammate on teammate crime," emphasizing how defensive pressure can exploit sloppy ball movement, reinforcing the need to improve passing.
D: Event 6: A discussion about Candace Parker deflecting injury questions during a Sparks–Mercury game, unrelated to passing fundamentals.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 7): The segment culminates in the audio line "teach each other some things and passing is definitely one of them," after audible strain, repeated attempts, crowd yells, and on-court action (visuals across the segment). Prior clips supply concrete evidence of passing problems and defensive pressure that justify this conclusion. In event 5, the audio explicitly describes confusion on a pass amid multiple misses before Alexis Jones recovers the ball; the visuals show ongoing live action on the Sparks court, bolstering the situational context—this directly points to a need for cleaner passing. In event 8, the audio highlights "inbound stolen" and a "terrible pass," plus transition pressure; the visuals show hectic sequences across games—again underscoring that poor passing leads to turnovers. In event 2’s All-Star setting, the audio remark "teammate on teammate crime" alongside defensive commentary and live game sounds, with visuals of elite players, suggests that defense punishes lax ball movement, reinforcing why passing must be emphasized. Event 6’s injury-discussion commentary is unrelated to passing fundamentals. Thus A, B, and C together create a cross-event causal build-up—via both audio play-by-play and supporting visuals—that logically leads to the teaching emphasis on passing heard in event 7.

question: In event 8, the narrator claims Kwame Brown's confidence drastically decreased after training with Michael Jordan. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly served as primary contributing factors to this confidence collapse? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: The creator’s apology for fewer uploads, fan shout-outs, and a brief upbeat music interlude.

B: Event 5: Training under Jordan described as incredibly tough, with the narrator alleging Jordan ritually reduced Brown to tears using offensive language, shown over intense coach-and-player scenes and No. 23 straining.

C: Event 7: The narrator characterizes Jordan as too aggressive and says he insulted Brown daily with harsh slurs, while visuals show tense late-game moments and Brown walking off the court in a charged arena.
D: Event 6: On-screen text shows Brown’s quote to a coach that he didn’t want to do it the night before being drafted, and the narrator explains he lacked confidence even before joining the NBA.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 8): The audio explicitly says Brown’s confidence drastically decreased after training with Jordan, while the visuals show the player in white No. 5 being interviewed postgame and making plays, framing the discussion around his on-court state. To identify causes, we synthesize earlier audio-visual evidence across events. Event 5 (audio) claims Jordan made practices incredibly tough and ritually reduced Brown to tears with offensive language; the visuals reinforce a high-pressure environment (coach directing, No. 23 bent over/straining). This plausibly erodes confidence. Event 7 (audio) further details Jordan’s too-aggressive personality and daily insults using slurs; visuals show a fraught competitive atmosphere (late-game scoreboards, Brown walking off), contextualizing the persistent verbal attacks that would wear down confidence. Event 6 contributes the preexisting fragility: the screen literally displays Brown’s quote about not wanting to do it before the draft, while the narrator explains he lacked confidence from the start; the visuals include a close-up of Brown and the tense end-game context, signaling vulnerability. Taken together—event 5’s abusive training practices and event 7’s daily insults acting upon the already low baseline from event 6—these form a multi-event causal chain leading to the confidence drop asserted in event 8. Event 2’s creator apology (A) is unrelated to Brown’s psychology or Jordan’s behavior and thus is not a cause.

question: In event 7, the host speculates that André Onana may leave Ajax for Europe—possibly the Premier League—and even hints at Chelsea as a destination. Which earlier sub-events most directly led to this speculative statement? Choose all that apply.

gold_reasoning: To understand why the host speculates in event 7 about Onana moving to Europe/Premier League and potentially Chelsea, we need both audio and visual cues across multiple prior events. In event 5 (visual), the screen shows tweets/images tied to Onana’s farewell (Ajax kit and empty stadium photo), and the audio quotes "the journey ends here" while explaining Ajax’s rebuild and Onana’s transfer value—this directly seeds the idea that he is leaving. In event 6 (audio), the host weighs Chelsea’s ability to carry both Onana and another keeper, a practical consideration that advances the Chelsea-specific angle. In event 0 (audio), the introduction already mentions Onana’s social media post about the journey ending at Ajax, establishing the transfer narrative from the outset. These combine to produce the event 7 outcome where the host says Onana might move to Europe, maybe even Chelsea. Event 8, however, focuses on forwards (audio) and includes no goalkeeper-specific visual or audio evidence, so it is not a primary driver of the goalkeeper speculation.

Causes span multiple earlier events and require both audio and video. In Event 5, the audio commentary (noisy play-by-play tone) details the first clash: grown men arguing over a foul ball, red and blue shirts converging, and a glove (“Santa glove”) knocking it away and bouncing off a chair—this establishes the contentious scramble and rivalry. question: Result sub-event: He finally concedes defeat and tells everyone to “take the rest of the day off,” saying “you stink… the whole thing stinks” (later segment). Which prior sub-events most plausibly drove him to that decision, considering both the on-screen Giants context and his escalating complaints?
options: A: His profane opening rant about losing to a team that was “0 and 9,” delivered in a furious tone while wearing GIANTS gear in front of the NY banner (event 0).
B: The public humiliation of being booed by his neighbor at his own home—where his wife sleeps and kids play—which he angrily recounts (event 8).

D: His story about a bad red‑eye flight and a prank with hair gel that sent someone to the hospital (event 2).
gold_reasoning: To infer why he grants everyone the rest of the day off in event 9, we must synthesize multiple earlier stressors tied directly to the team’s performance, using both visuals and audio. Audio in event 0 establishes the humiliating context—he explodes about losing to an “0 and 9” team with extreme profanity. Visually, throughout these segments he is unmistakably aligned with the New York Giants—the GIANTS shirt and the large NY banner (noted in events 0, 5, and 9) anchor the rant to this specific team context. Event 5 deepens the football-specific cause: he details the on-field failings (secondary is a mess) and cites the season’s plunge from 11–5 to 1–8, explicitly blaming coaching—this is performance-centered and intensifies his despair. Event 8 adds social pressure beyond the field: he recounts being booed by his neighbor at his own home—emotionally charged audio that signals public embarrassment and personal invasion. The combination of (a) the humiliating loss (event 0, with the visual NY/GIANTS framing), (b) structural performance collapse (event 5, also under the same visual branding), and (c) personal/public backlash (event 8) builds to the result in event 9 where, on the same Giants backdrop, he audibly concedes, “take the rest of the day off… the whole thing stinks.” The flight/prank story in event 2 is agitation but not a primary, team-performance cause of that leadership decision.

question: Result sub-event: He prepares for a tough conference call with ownership and angrily orders someone to get out of his locker room, repeating “no blinking” (later segment). gold_reasoning: The locker-room ejection and “no blinking” command in event 10 follow a cumulative chain of performance and accountability grievances evidenced in both audio and visuals. In event 3, he audibly stresses that the organization has supplied “first class” resources (cleats, food, locker room), a standard visually underlined by the consistent professional Giants setup (NY banner, MYBOOKIE sign), implying players/staff have no excuse—this sets an accountability baseline. Event 5 escalates performance failure: he says the secondary is a mess and the record fell from 11–5 to 1–8, blaming coaching; visually he remains in the Giants-branded frame, reinforcing that these are in-house problems. Event 7 peaks the condemnation: he labels the product “Big Blue Shit,” with an angry tone and a dramatic sting, signaling a public and emotional breaking point under the same Giants imagery. These three prior sub-events together create an arc from provided support (event 3) to undeniable failure (event 5) to outright denunciation (event 7), which plausibly culminates in event 10’s zero‑tolerance behavior—prepping for a tense ownership call and audibly ejecting someone from “my locker room.” The flight/prank anecdote in event 2, while aggravating, is peripheral to the direct football accountability chain that triggers the ejection.

question: Result sub-event: In event 9, the speaker excitedly says he will lead the Buckeyes out of the tunnel in front of 110,000 people and catalogs traditions like the band, students, and Quik Cals. gold_reasoning: To understand the excitement about leading the team out of the tunnel in event 9 (audio: “lead the Buckeyes out of the tunnel … band … student body … Quik Cals”; visuals: the marching band performing and crowd energy), we need both audio and visual cues from earlier events. In event 6, the audio explicitly states his own tradition of running out of the tunnel to reset his mindset—“to be aggressive” and to look at the audience—while the visuals reinforce this with players bursting onto the field through smoke. This directly foreshadows and motivates the event 9 intention. In event 2, the audio spells out his desire to be a Buckeye precisely to embrace the program’s traditions and rivalry, and the visuals show him in Ohio Stadium, linking his motivation to the venue and its customs. These two earlier sub-events together (event 6’s tunnel ritual and event 2’s tradition-centric motivation) causally explain why, in event 9, he eagerly focuses on leading out of the tunnel and celebrating traditions. By contrast, event 1’s leadership/responsibility talk is broader and not directly about tunnel/traditions, and event 7’s rivalry emphasis is about Michigan’s enormity rather than the act of leading the team out or the specific traditions cited in event 9.

question: In event 15, the host concludes that Giannis has a “very, very good chance to get that third MVP.” Which earlier sub-events most directly led to this conclusion? Select all that apply.

Event 5 strengthens this with both modalities: visually we see Giannis (#34 in green) dribbling and preparing to shoot versus the Jazz, while the audio details his sped-up jump-shot sequence and predicts no more crowd counting; this specific mechanical improvement is presented as performance evidence. Event 14 adds an audio-visual odds board and discussion of voter dynamics (Vegas odds and player fatigue), giving a macro rationale that, combined with the skill improvements, supports the MVP forecast. question: In event 12, the drill advances to “Find a Friend – Progression 4,” shifting to a 4v4 keep-ball format using target players who play with the team in possession. Which earlier steps most directly led to this possession-focused, rotation-based progression being introduced? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 9: The coach introduces teams of four with diagonal target players, emphasizing finding space, supporting the ball, and possible direct passes.
B: Event 10: Instructions and visuals that middle players combine to pass into the opposite target player, and the passer takes the target player’s place (rotation).

gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 12 transitions to Progression 4 with a 4v4 keep-ball using target players. This progression emerges from a multi-event buildup. In Event 9, the coach (audio) describes a progression with teams of four, aiming to combine and support the ball, and the visuals show diagonal target positioning—this sets the possession structure and spatial roles needed for 4v4 (audio + visual cause). In Event 10, visuals and on-screen text show “Middle players now combine to pass into opposite target player” and “Target player and middle player rotate positions,” while the coach (audio) explains that the player who passes takes the target player’s place—this introduces combination play and rotation essential for possession play (audio + visual cause). In Event 11, the rotation concept is reinforced: the screen text explicitly states “Target player and middle player rotate positions,” and the coach (audio) instructs that players swap positions—this consolidates the rotation mechanism that underpins the 4v4 keep-ball approach (audio + visual cause). Event 1 focuses on early rules about reacting and passing to the opposition team’s target players and does not establish the 4v4 keep-ball with rotation, so it does not directly cause the shift in Event 12.

question: Result sub-event: In event 5, the narrator says Vince Carter was “dealt to the Nets,” framed by a Sam Mitchell graphic, after noting that a “ploy didn’t work.” Which preceding sub-events most plausibly drove the organization toward trading him? Select all that apply.

question: Result sub-event: In event 12, the presenter asserts that a certain saddle type "doesn't really have any place on a road bike" and should be reserved for triathlon/time trials, noting its poor pelvis support for road use. Which preceding sub-events most directly caused or led to this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 8 – The critique of the “noseless saddle” concept: excessive rear width drives riders toward a non-existent nose, exposing design issues that undermine stable support.
B: Event 6 – Emphasis that most customers end up on a certain flat, channeled saddle (e.g., from Specialized/Bontrager), highlighting preferred features.
C: Event 11 – The explanation that the ISM PM 3.1 is a time-trial/triathlon saddle designed to load the pelvis further forward in a more anteriorly rotated position.
D: Event 10 – The argument that pros’ use of “noseless saddles” shouldn’t drive consumer choices and the speaker’s report of much better success with traditional flat saddles for everyday riders.
gold_reasoning: To reach the event 12 conclusion (audio: he says the saddle type "doesn't really have any place on a road bike" and should only be for triathlon/time trials), the presenter builds a case across earlier segments using both what we hear and what we see. In event 11 (audio), he explicitly identifies the ISM PM 3.1 as a TT/tri saddle that loads the pelvis further forward for an anteriorly rotated position; visually he demonstrates with the pelvis model, tying the saddle’s intended posture to non-road scenarios. In event 8 (audio), he criticizes the noseless concept, explaining the excessive rear width tends to push riders toward the nose—visually he gestures with a tablet while explaining—underscoring structural reasons the design fails to provide stable support on a road bike. In event 10 (audio), he further argues that pros’ use (often sponsor-driven) shouldn’t dictate everyday choices and reports “a hell of a lot more success” with traditional flat saddles; visually he inspects a saddle while making this point. These three together (events 8, 10, 11) directly motivate the event 12 verdict that such a saddle belongs in TT/tri contexts, not on road bikes. Event 6 is less causally relevant; while it praises certain flat, channeled saddles (audio) and shows him handling a product (visual), it doesn’t specifically argue the road unsuitability of noseless/TT saddles, so it is not a primary cause of the event 12 conclusion.

question: In Event 5, the video concludes on-screen and in narration that attaching the foot to the pedal does not improve efficiency and that different shoe–pedal combinations had no significant effect on metabolic cost (followed by a sarcastic “Nope, unsubscribed”). Which earlier sub-events most directly built the causal case for this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 4: The Straw & Kram paper is shown while the speaker states there was no significant effect of shoe–pedal condition on metabolic power or oxygen consumption.
B: Event 3: The gross efficiency study is discussed with on-screen methodology and narration noting mean VO2 was 2.1% higher with toe clips, implying worse efficiency with attachment.
C: Event 1: The elite cyclist technique study appears with narration that 97% of work is from the downstroke and that pulling up reduces efficiency.
D: Event 7: The EMG article is displayed with narration saying clipless pedals showed less EMG activity, but the study did not assess efficiency.
gold_reasoning: Event 5’s result sub-event—stating no efficiency gain from foot attachment and summarizing no significant metabolic-cost differences—follows a chain built by multiple prior studies shown and explained. Event 4 visually presents the Straw & Kram paper while the speaker audibly reports no significant effect on metabolic power or oxygen consumption across shoe–pedal interfaces; this directly supports the Event 5 on-screen summary. Event 3 visually and textually outlines a toe-clip study and, in audio, the speaker notes VO2 was 2.1% higher with toe clips, implying worse efficiency when the foot is attached—again reinforcing the Event 5 conclusion. Event 1 shows the elite-cyclist technique paper and, in audio, the speaker explains that 97% of work is from the downstroke and that trying to pull up reduces efficiency, undermining the idea that attachment improves efficiency. question: Result sub-event: In event 14, the presenter shows a drawing of Haiti with Twitter and YouTube icons and a timeline of just a few hours, while stating that news spread rapidly and the entire human race entered an “empathic embrace.” Which prior event(s) most directly caused/enabled this rapid, global empathic response? Event 10 (cause) extends the scope: visuals of “HOMO-EMPATHICUS,” historical eras, and a hand holding the Earth; audio explicitly asks if we can extend empathy to the entire human race and biosphere—exactly the scaling required to cohere larger social units. These three together causally underwrite the event 11 conclusion. question: In event 9, the speaker concludes with the “Vector’s Vision Of Future” slide (TODAY: Hardware Centric $100M Years → TOMORROW: Software Centric <$1M Months) and states they will transform space with software-based innovation. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly underpin and directly lead to this software-centric vision? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 3: On “Lowering Barriers To Space Access,” the speaker introduces software-defined satellites for Galactic Sky (2019) and says users will program satellites “like you would a cellphone with apps.”

B: Event 1: The “A New Space Race Is Here” and “Microsatellite Disruption” framing with audio explaining that modern satellites are smaller, cheaper, and faster to develop due to a new entrepreneurial generation.

C: Event 2: The detailed comparison slide quantifying micro satellites’ 20 kg average mass, 0.1–1M USD cost, and <1 year development time, reinforcing the feasibility of rapid, lower-cost (software-like) cycles.
D: Event 7: The sequence of early test flights (desert, Georgia) with rocket noise and mention of upcoming Virginia orbital flights, emphasizing vehicle testing milestones.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 9): Visually, the split-screen “Vector’s Vision Of Future” contrasts TODAY (Hardware Centric $100M Years) with TOMORROW (Software Centric <$1M Months); audibly, the speaker declares a shift to software-based innovation via launch vehicles and a Galactic Sky constellation. The causal reasoning draws on at least three prior events. Event 3 provides direct software evidence: the slide explicitly lists “software-defined satellites for Galactic Sky (2019),” and the speaker says satellites will be programmable “like a cellphone with apps,” clearly foreshadowing the software-centric end state. Event 1 establishes the overarching disruption: visuals (“A New Space Race Is Here” and “Microsatellite Disruption”) and audio describing smaller, cheaper, faster satellites created by entrepreneurs—conditions that make software-speed iteration possible. Event 2 then quantifies this disruption: visuals show micro satellites’ low mass, sub-$1M cost, and <1-year timelines, aligning with the TOMORROW column’s <$1M and months. Together, these prior sub-events logically lead to the event 9 vision. Event 7’s flight-test montage, while evidencing technical progress, pertains to hardware validation and does not directly justify the software-centric transformation.

question: Result sub-event: In event 12, while maps of African land at risk of drought and flooding are shown, a male panelist focuses on climate change as a major cause of migration, and the statement draws applause. Which earlier interventions most plausibly led to this climate-focused response and the display of those risk maps? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 9 – The audience member closes her multi-part intervention by stating that the biggest threat to Tunisia in the next ten years is drought and floods, thanks the panel, and the audience applauds.
B: Event 7 – The audience member challenges the status quo, suggests Daesh stands as a policy preference, and asks the room where the threat really is, prompting a reframing of risks.
C: Event 0 – The moderator announces the session format that explicitly includes questions from Mo Ibrahim fellows and scholars, enabling the intervention from the floor to shape the panel’s topics.
D: Event 3 – The moderator’s formal introduction of panelists (e.g., Jean-Marie Guehenno and Martin Kobler) and their credentials.
gold_reasoning: The causal chain spans events 0, 7, 9, and culminates in 12, requiring both audio and visual evidence. Event 0’s audio sets the ground rules that fellows/scholars will ask questions, making the subsequent audience intervention possible. Visually in events 4–8 we see the woman in a green top speaking at a floor microphone; in event 7, the audio captures her challenging the prevailing focus and asking where the real threat lies, steering the discussion toward reassessing risks. In event 9, she explicitly states on audio that drought and floods are Tunisia’s biggest looming threats and then thanks the panel; applause follows, indicating the panel’s cue to respond. In event 12, the visuals show maps of drought and flood risk across Africa, and the audio has a panelist emphasizing climate change as a major cause of migration, followed by applause—clearly echoing and expanding on the audience member’s risk framing from events 7 and 9. Event 3’s introductions provide context for who is speaking but are not a primary driver of the climate-focused response or the choice to show drought/flood maps.

question: What prior events most plausibly led to the result sub-event in event 5 where she emerges as a fervent advocate for environmental justice (shown by the megaphone and environmental scenes)? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: Social consciousness awakening through storytelling—using craft to unveil societal intricacies and subtleties of life.
B: Event 3: Recognition of social injustices becomes her compass toward a purposeful existence (stop/social/injustice signs).
C: Event 4: Intertwining compassion with activism and the purposeful impact of her literary success, establishing a platform to act.
D: Event 1: Introductory montage and narration about Insightrove and intentional living presented with cosmic imagery and art studio scenes.
gold_reasoning: The result sub-event appears in event 5: visuals show “Advocacy for Environmental Justice,” a megaphone, and hands-on environmental scenes, while the audio states she emerged as an advocate whose intentional living extended beyond literature. The causal chain draws on at least three earlier events. (A) Event 2 lays the foundation: the visuals label her as “STORYTELLER” and explicitly display “Social Consciousness Awakening,” while the audio explains she used her craft to reveal societal intricacies—seeding the awareness necessary for later environmental advocacy. (B) Event 3 converts awareness into a moral compass: visuals of stop/social/injustice signs and the audio’s emphasis that recognition of injustice guided her toward purpose establish a directional push toward action. (C) Event 4 provides the platform and purposeful intent: visuals highlight “The Impact of ‘The God of Small Things’ – Literary Success with Purpose,” and the audio notes her publication transformed her into a luminary who intertwined life with compassionate activism—equipping her with influence to champion causes like environmental justice. Together, these visual and audio elements across events 2, 3, and 4 directly feed into the outcome in event 5. (D) Event 1 is thematic scene-setting; its visuals and audio introduce intentional living in general but do not supply the specific awareness-justice-platform chain that precipitates environmental justice advocacy.

question: In event 8, the speaker describes launching a walk that began on January 11 and ended January 24 in New Hampshire to make “that death not meaningless,” while the screen shows a New Hampshire map highlighting Dixville Notch and Nashua. Which earlier sub-events most directly motivated this commemorative walk?
options: A: Aaron Swartz challenges the speaker years earlier about how to solve problems like copyright policy given government corruption, pressing the speaker on his duty as a citizen (event 6).
B: The announcement of Aaron Swartz’s suicide and commentary that prosecutors wouldn’t stop until he pled as a felon, framing his death as a grave injustice (event 7).
C: Granny D’s example: the account and visuals of her long reform walk for campaign finance, revealing public passion/anger around the issue (event 9).
D: Early remarks that internet creativity tools became tools of speech and that government/industry sought to surveil and control speech (event 1).
gold_reasoning: The result sub-event in event 8 is both seen and heard: video shows a New Hampshire map (Dixville Notch and Nashua) while the audio states an “urgency to make that death not meaningless,” dates the walk from January 11 to January 24, notes “200 people joined us,” and says they arrived on the anniversary of “Granny D’s” birth. The death referenced audibly in event 8 points back to event 7, where the audio soberly announces Aaron Swartz’s suicide and describes prosecutorial pressure; this establishes the death as the galvanizing cause. Event 6 provides additional causal context: the audio recounts Aaron’s earlier pointed question to the speaker about tackling corruption and the speaker’s responsibility as a citizen—seeding the motivation for action beyond internet-specific issues. Event 9 supplies the model and timing rationale: audio describes Granny D’s long walk for campaign finance reform, and video shows her walking with a “GRANNY D FOR CAMPAIGN” bib; tying the event 8 timing (arriving on her birth anniversary) and method (a walk) directly to her example. Event 1, while thematically related to internet freedom and surveillance (audio) and shows the speaker in TED/studio contexts (video), does not specifically explain a memorial walk nor the New Hampshire focus, so it is not a direct cause. Answering correctly requires audio (event 8’s purpose and dates; event 7’s suicide announcement; event 6’s challenge; event 9’s narrative) and video (event 8’s NH map; event 9’s walking imagery and bib) across at least three events to link the motivations.

question: At the end of event 13, a bold graphic reads “FIX DEMOCRACY FIRST” while speakers describe a system that is “rigged” and commit to erasing inequality. Which earlier events most directly build the case for that concluding call?
options: A: Granny D’s cross-country walk for campaign finance reform and the narrator’s surprise at the passion and anger surrounding the issue (event 9).

B: The on-screen “96%” statistic and explanation that nearly all Americans want to reduce money’s influence, plus the note that candidates must raise funds from a tiny fraction of the 1% to run (event 10).

C: The argument that many urgent issues (climate, debt, economy) are tied to the corrupting influence of money in politics, paired with visuals of the Capitol, Wall St., and Lincoln Memorial (event 12).
D: The introduction of Edward Snowden and claims of sweeping wiretap authority, with audience applause (event 2).
gold_reasoning: The result sub-event in event 13 consists of a closing visual—“FIX DEMOCRACY FIRST”—and audio asserting the system is “rigged” and emphasizing equality. Event 10 provides quantitative public backing: audio cites a poll showing “96% of Americans” want to reduce money’s influence, and the video overlays a large “96%,” substantiating the breadth of concern that underpins the call to fix democracy. Event 12 gives the root-cause frame: the audio explicitly links diverse policy challenges to the corrupting influence of money in politics, while video shows national symbols (Capitol, Wall St., Lincoln Memorial), visually situating the problem in American governance and finance—directly justifying a democracy-first reform agenda. Event 9 supplies the activist precedent and emotional force: audio recounts Granny D’s reform walk and the narrator’s astonishment at the public’s passion/anger; video shows her walking with a campaign bib, illustrating sustained citizen mobilization for campaign-finance reform. Event 2, while thematically about civil liberties and surveillance (audio) with interviews and applause (video), does not specifically build the money-in-politics case that culminates in the “Fix Democracy First” mandate. Determining the correct causes requires integrating audio (poll numbers, corruption-as-root-cause argument, campaign-finance activism) and video (the “96%” overlay, national landmarks, Granny D’s walking imagery) across multiple earlier events.

question: In event 7, the speaker shows two artworks on the slide titled “3. Opportunities in Difficulties” and explains she found the opportunity to pursue her passion for art. Which preceding sub-events most directly led to this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 6: She could not attend school regularly and therefore chose math and art as her subjects, framing it as finding “opportunities in difficulties.”
B: Event 4: While bedridden, she focused on what she could still do (e.g., a wheelchair photo shoot), shifting attention from limitations to abilities.
C: Event 1: She urged the audience to believe in miracles, showing survival percentages and her hope that her lungs can be cured.
D: Event 10: She recommended getting a dog and said pets are the best medicine, mentioning Kobe the Labrador.
gold_reasoning: To see why the artworks in event 7 are a direct result of earlier causes, both the visuals and audio across events 4, 6, and 7 must be integrated. In event 7 (visual), the slide explicitly displays “3. Opportunities in Difficulties” and shows two specific artworks; in audio, she states she found the opportunity to pursue art and describes the pieces (a portrait in dry pastels and album art). This result traces back to event 6 (audio), where she explains she couldn’t attend school regularly and therefore chose math and art—explicitly connecting difficulty to the new pursuit; the visual also reinforces the theme with the same “Opportunities in Difficulties” title. Event 4 (visual) shows a wheelchair image and the stage screen with “INK”; in audio, she recounts being bedridden, intentionally focusing on what she could still do (e.g., a modeling photo shoot), which evidences a mindset of shifting focus to abilities. That mindset directly supports the later choice to channel effort into art. By contrast, event 1 (belief in miracles) and event 10 (get a dog) align with her broader story but do not specifically set up the art-making seen in event 7.

question: Target result sub-event: In event 6, the speaker presents "Green Village," a community of 30 custom bamboo homes, highlighting their bamboo model-making and 3D-to-craft workflow. Which earlier events most directly enabled this project to exist and be executed as shown and described? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: The realization (with visuals of bamboo) and narration that borax treatment makes bamboo a permanent building material, inspiring many.
B: Event 4: The founding of "Ibuku" (audio explanation of the name) and the formation of a visible, cohesive team in green shirts in a forest setting.
C: Event 5: Assembling an incredible team of artisans and builders (audio), shown onstage with group imagery; young professionals pioneering a new future.
D: Event 1: The period in New York where her prints appeared on runways and she built a fabulous wardrobe.
gold_reasoning: The result sub-event is the Green Village project presentation in event 6 (audio: a community of 30 homes with a bamboo model-making and digital replication process; visuals: bamboo house imagery, hands-on model craft, and a stage slide with 3D design). Establishing how this became possible requires synthesizing both modalities across earlier events: (A) Event 2 supplies the material foundation—audio details bamboo’s growth and the borax treatment (Linda Garland’s innovation) that makes bamboo permanent; visuals reinforce bamboo’s centrality. Without durable bamboo, a long-lived community is untenable. (B) Event 4 marks the organizational vehicle—audio declares she founded “Ibuku,” while visuals show a large, unified team in matching green shirts in a forest. This company and team structure are necessary to undertake a 30-home development. (C) Event 5 adds the execution capacity—audio emphasizes an incredible group of artisans and builders (linked to Green School) who are young professionals; visuals onstage show group imagery. These are the craftspeople who translate models and 3D designs into built forms. (D) Event 1, though part of her earlier career arc, focuses on fashion runways and does not directly enable a bamboo community’s realization; it lacks the material, organizational, and craft linkages that A–C provide.

question: In event 7, the speaker shows the Buddha Doodles book and audibly announces she has signed with a publisher and that the book is available for pre-order. Which earlier events most directly set up that publishing deal? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: Excelling in math and later healing from PTSD through therapy, art, and mindfulness.
B: Event 3: Touring with her own illustrated, self-published books at comic conventions and connecting with audiences.
C: Event 5: Spinning off a daily sketch practice into “Boodadoodles,” posting it online, and it going viral.
D: Event 6: Growing Buddha Doodles into an online gift shop and a large community, running a six-figure business and donating to charities.
gold_reasoning: To confirm the result sub-event, event 7’s visuals show a Buddha Doodles book (cover and an interior page like “Dream Big”), while the audio explicitly states she signed with a publisher and the book is available for pre-order. Tracing causes across prior events requires both visual and audio cues: (B) Event 3’s audio details that she toured comic conventions with her illustrated, self-published books, and felt rewarded by connecting with audiences; visually, the sequence frames themes of resilience (“Through darkness, we find light”), reinforcing her body of work and readership—this audience groundwork plausibly feeds into publisher interest. (C) Event 5’s audio explains she launched “Boodadoodles” from her daily sketch practice and posted it online where it went viral; the visuals present character-driven, comic-like creative scenes, indicating the format that spread online—viral reach is a direct precursor to a publisher deal. (D) Event 6’s audio describes scaling Buddha Doodles into an online gift shop, building a community, and running a six-figure business with charitable giving; visuals include hallmark inspirational panels (“This too shall pass,” “Give thanks for this day”), evidencing a recognizable brand—demonstrated market traction and community size are strong drivers for a publisher partnership. (A) Event 2 concerns academic success and personal healing (audio), and its visuals center on math ability and inner growth; while important context, it does not directly explain the commercial and audience factors that lead to a publisher signing, thus it’s not a primary cause of the event 7 outcome.

question: In event 7, the result sub-event shows the on-screen label "4. Spark innovation" over a UPS truck while the speaker explains UPS’s right-turn routing to save fuel. Which preceding events or sub-events most directly laid the step-by-step foundation that led to this innovation example being presented? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 6: The on-screen sequence of “1. Heighten awareness,” “2. Identify trends,” and “3. Discover opportunities,” while the speaker narrates police observation training, Henry Ford’s pay decision, and Mercedes’ boxfish-inspired car design.

B: Event 5: The urban roundabout transitioning to a historical painting with the on-screen text “1. Heighten awareness,” while the speaker describes Dutch intersections removing signs so people must relate to each other and accidents drop.
C: Event 4: The designer-focused segment with a vintage radio on white as the speaker discusses Dieter Rams’s philosophy of stripping away the unnecessary and Apple’s inspiration from it.
D: Event 1: The logo trio (FedEx, Toblerone, Australian logo) on white as the speaker enthusiastically points out hidden elements like the arrow and the bear.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 7): Visually, the screen labels the step “4. Spark innovation” and shows a UPS truck; aurally, the speaker explains the fuel-saving right-turn routing. This is framed as the next step in a structured process. The immediate causal groundwork is laid in earlier steps: Event 6 visually displays the numbered steps “1. Heighten awareness,” “2. Identify trends,” and “3. Discover opportunities,” while the audio ties each to concrete cases (police training, Henry Ford’s pay change, Mercedes biomimicry). This pairing of visuals and narration establishes a process that logically precedes step 4. Event 5 further anchors step 1: on screen the text “1. Heighten awareness” appears along with the painting and the city scene, while the audio details the Dutch intersection redesign that improved safety by forcing mutual attention—an applied example of heightened awareness. Together, these two events (5 and 6) create the step-by-step framework that culminates in event 7’s “Spark innovation” example. Event 4 (Rams/Apple) and Event 1 (logos) are plausible observation-related anecdotes, but they are not the explicit stepwise precursors visually and verbally tied to the numbered process that directly yields step 4 in event 7.

question: In event 12, the presenter excitedly introduces “Miss Haley” after announcing she was accepted to her number-one choice with an academic scholarship. Which earlier sub-events most directly contributed to this result? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 3: After a psycho-educational assessment in 2010 revealed slower processing speed, she switched schools and began her sophomore year at Assets High School.
B: Event 11: At her new high school, caring teachers helped her come out of her shell, find her strengths, and become a successful student.
C: Event 8: A reading-level program placed her at a high-school level; after a skeptical teacher made her retake it, she earned the same high score, proving her capability despite ADHD bias.
D: Event 14: A general explanation about dyslexia/dysgraphia and a mention of Arwin’s processing speed.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 12 shows (visual) two presenters on stage with a large projected image (eye transitioning to a smiling face) as the speaker, in an enthusiastic tone (audio), announces Haley’s acceptance and scholarship and then introduces “Miss Haley.” The direct causes are evidenced across multiple prior events: (Event 3) Audio describes a psycho-educational assessment identifying slower processing speed and the student switching to Assets High School; visually, the same two-person stage setup maintains context that this is a continuous personal narrative. That school change sets the structural support for improvement. (Event 11) Audio explicitly states that at the new high school, teachers cared about subjects and students, helping the girl come out of her shell and become successful; visually, the same presenters stand by slides (electronics, eye) showing an ongoing, detailed presentation of this journey. This directly precedes and explains how she became scholarship-ready. (Event 8) Audio recounts the reading test scenario where, despite teacher skepticism due to ADHD, she confirmed a high reading level on retake; visually, the speaker is on stage holding paper while presenting a travel photo, reinforcing this is the same student story. This incident demonstrates academic capability overcoming bias, contributing to the academic success that leads to acceptance and a scholarship in Event 12. By contrast, (Event 14) is a general discussion about dyslexia/dysgraphia and Arwin’s processing speed, which is thematically related but pertains to another person and does not directly cause Haley’s acceptance announcement.

question: In event 16, the on-stage speaker concludes that “learning differences are not bad” and students “just need accommodations and someone to believe in them.” Which prior moments most directly set up this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 15: The speaker stresses concrete coping skills (note cards, technology, simple lists) and explains it took her a long time to build a system, implying supports enable success.
B: Event 13: The speaker explains ADHD manifests differently even within the inattentive type (e.g., daydreaming vs. hyper-focus), highlighting variation rather than inferiority.
C: Event 11: The story of a girl thriving at a new high school where teachers care, helping her find strengths and become successful.
D: Event 0: An opening montage of negative labels (“stupid, lazy, hopeless”) directed at kids.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 16 shows (visual) two presenters with leis standing side-by-side on stage as the speaker asserts (audio) that learning differences aren’t bad and students need accommodations and belief. This conclusion is built by earlier audio-visual evidence: (Event 15) Visually, a slide titled “Cognitive Assessment” is on screen while the speaker (audio) details coping strategies—note cards, tech, lists—and admits it took her “whole life to find a system,” directly illustrating that supports/accommodations drive achievement. (Event 13) Visually, two women co-present; the speaker (audio) explains ADHD manifests differently even for people with the same inattentive type (music stuck in head/daydreaming vs. her hyper-focus). This undercuts the notion of “bad” and reframes differences as variation, supporting the later conclusion. (Event 11) The narrative (audio) of a girl flourishing at a new high school with caring teachers shows that belief and appropriate support lead to success; visually, the presenters and slides (electronics, eye) keep continuity of the same story. While (Event 0) presents negative labels (audio) over a title card (visual), it serves as context for stigma but does not directly demonstrate how accommodations and belief cause success; the direct causal setup comes from Events 15, 13, and 11 showing mechanisms and outcomes that justify the Event 16 conclusion.

question: Target result sub-event: In event 10, the narrator says that over 200 white supremacists have “hung up their robes,” while we see Daryl folding a white robe and are told many robes now hang in his closet. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly served as the primary causes of this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: Daryl spends decades engaging and befriending KKK members, even shaking hands with an Imperial Wizard and asking, “How can you hate me when you don’t even know me?”
B: Event 8: Daryl explicitly supports their freedom of speech, saying they reciprocate it, applying a rapport-building approach.
C: Event 14: A public figure declares that “the discourse is over,” signaling an end to talking.
D: Event 0: Violent street clashes and the narrator’s early question about escalating the conflict instead of talking.
gold_reasoning: To understand why many robes end up in Daryl’s closet (event 10), we need both the visual and audio trail across multiple prior events. In event 2 (video), we repeatedly see Daryl sitting with KKK members, shaking hands with Imperial Wizard Frank Ancona, and speaking publicly; the audio underscores his ethic with the reflective line, “How can you hate me when you don’t even know me?” This combination of images and words establishes his long-term, personal engagement strategy. In event 8 (audio), Daryl states he does not support racist agendas but supports their right to free speech and that “they reciprocate it.” Visually, he is seen calmly addressing audiences, reinforcing that his approach fosters mutual respect. Event 7’s audio explicitly frames the persuasion mechanism—reciprocity—explaining why respect and kindness tend to be returned; coupled with event 8, this makes clear how his method could cause attitude change. Finally, event 10’s visuals of Daryl folding the robe, along with the audio stating “over 200… hung up their robes,” presents the concrete result of those relationships. By contrast, event 14’s declaration that discourse is “over” (audio) and event 0’s violent clashes (video) neither align with nor explain the peaceful conversions leading to surrendered robes. Thus, the causally relevant contributors are Daryl’s sustained, face-to-face friendships (event 2) and his explicit, reciprocated commitment to their speech rights (event 8), which, per the reciprocity principle (event 7 audio context), plausibly led to the conversions manifested in event 10.

question: In event 3, the speaker says they created the “Goddamn World Championships of Rock Paper Scissors.” Which earlier event sub-events most plausibly enabled that championship to launch? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 1: The speaker’s origin story of an intense match with his brother that led to founding the World Rock Paper Scissors Society, as he explains while slides and symbolic imagery (e.g., a clenched fist) appear behind him.
B: Event 2: Building the game’s culture by launching a website, defining gambits, and adopting movement-style imagery, as described while the WRPS logo, gambit names, and posters are shown on screen.
C: Event 5: Earning a Guinness World Record in 2008 for the largest rock paper scissors contest, shown alongside the Guinness cover on screen.
D: Event 3 (earlier in the segment): Selling memberships and merchandise that grew the movement, illustrated by the on-screen membership card and reinforced by the speaker’s narration.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: the creation of the World Championships (event 3). The causal chain spans multiple earlier events and uses both audio and visual cues. In event 1 (audio), the speaker recounts how an intense match with his brother led to creating the World Rock Paper Scissors Society; visually, we see the formal presentation context and symbolic imagery (like the clenched fist), signaling an organized effort. In event 2 (audio), he explains that they launched a website, defined gambits, and invented a culture/history around the game; visually, the WRPS logo, gambit names (e.g., “The Avalanche,” “Scissor Sandwich”), and propaganda-style posters appear, showing structured branding and strategy. In event 3 (audio), he explicitly says they sold memberships and merchandise, which “worked really, really well” and led to creating the championships; visually, the membership card, trophy image, and media collage reinforce that growth. By contrast, event 5’s Guinness record appears later (visual: Guinness 2008 cover; audio: largest contest) and is an outcome of earlier growth, not a cause of the championships. Therefore A, B, and D are the primary contributing causes.

question: Which earlier segments most directly set up the on-screen shift to “Evidence-Based Wisdom” and the speaker’s emphasis on valuing wisdom and virtues over raw intelligence that appears in event 10? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 4: The critique of appeals to false authority, with on-screen quotes while the speaker warns against trusting celebrity or out-of-domain expert advice.
B: Event 5: The introduction of the book The Intelligence Trap and the speaker’s distinction between intelligence and wisdom, shown alongside the book cover and contrasting imagery.
C: Event 8: The research segment with a comparative graph as the speaker explains that high intelligence doesn’t protect against biases or poor decisions.
