gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 13, the visuals explicitly show "Carbon Fusion" followed by "Explosion" and "Implosion," culminating in on-screen text "= Type I Supernova," while the narrator identifies this sequence as causing a Type I supernova. The causal chain relies on both audio and visuals across prior events. From event 12 (audio), the speaker clearly describes a carbon detonation supernova mechanism in a white dwarf that steals mass in a binary; visually, the screen labels it "Carbon Detonation Supernova" and the dwarf points at "Mass." This directly sets up the carbon-driven trigger referenced in event 13 before the Type I label appears. Event 11 provides the classification criterion: the narrator states that Type I has less hydrogen and Type II has more, and the visuals reinforce this with the on-screen comparison and note that Type II happens with high-mass stars. Those details justify why the carbon-driven scenario aligns with Type I. Event 10 introduces the taxonomy itself: the audio mentions there are different types (Type I and Type II), while the visuals display "Different Types of Supernova" and the labels "Type I" and "Type II," establishing the context needed for event 13’s classification to be meaningful. Together, these three events prepare and cause the Type I designation shown in event 13. Event 2, while related to stellar mass and white dwarfs (visuals/text about low-mass stars and audio saying they can only burn H and He), does not directly establish the Type I classification for the event 13 explosion; it’s background about stellar evolution rather than the immediate mechanism and classification criteria used to label the event as Type I.

question: In event 17, the screen shows a circular "Star → Nebula → Supernova" diagram while the narrator calls this process "stellar recycling." Which earlier events/sub-events together most directly lead to this recycling depiction? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 14 — Nebulae are explained as clouds of gas and dust that are remnants of detonated stars (visuals: labeled nebulae; audio mentions remnants and gives an example).
B: Event 16 — It’s explained that stars are created inside nebulae, and nebulae come from dying stars (visuals: "Nebula → Star" arrow; audio answers the question about new stars).

C: Event 15 — The explosion’s role in creating and spreading heavy elements is summarized (visuals: "Heavy Elements," "Periodic Table Complete"; audio: stellar nucleosynthesis, helium capture, neutron capture).
D: Event 9 — The narrator simplifies to "the star goes boom" and asks how big the boom is (visuals: cuts to a bright star and a prompt to the viewer).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 17, the visual is a circular diagram linking "Star," "Nebula," and "Supernova," and the audio explicitly names the concept "stellar recycling," explaining that stars synthesize heavy elements and spread dust that forms new stars and planets. The causal chain is grounded in earlier visual and audio cues. Event 14 establishes one link of the loop: the audio states that nebulae are remnants of stars that have detonated, while the visuals label nebulae as clouds of gas and dust that were once part of a star. Event 16 completes the loop in the opposite direction: the audio directly answers that stars form inside nebulae, and the visuals show a clear "Nebula → Star" arrow. Event 15 supplies the material basis for recycling: the audio summarizes heavy-element creation via stellar nucleosynthesis (including helium and neutron capture), and the visuals emphasize "Heavy Elements" and "Periodic Table Complete," making it clear that supernovae enrich the nebulae with new material. These three pieces together causally support the event 17 depiction and narration of a cyclical process. Event 9 merely states that a star explodes ("the star goes boom") without connecting that explosion to nebula formation, star birth, or element dispersal; it’s insufficient to establish the recycling cycle shown and named in event 17.

question: In event 11, the narrator admits he failed to record the moon’s surface while it was inside Earth’s umbra. Which earlier factors most directly caused this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Earlier sequences (event 9) were recorded at ISO 100, aperture 11, and 25 ms shutter, producing low-contrast images where the reddish shadowed surface was hard to see.
B: The Raspberry Pi camera (event 4) cannot control the lens aperture and uses a much smaller sensor, limiting how the exposure/aperture could be set.
C: The improvised adapter and flange setup (event 2)—using a 20 mm spacer that was “no perfect solution”—compromised the optical setup compared with a dedicated adapter.
D: A plane crossed the moon and the telescope was rotated to keep the moon moving horizontally across the screen (event 14).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 11 (audio), the speaker states he failed to record the moon’s surface in the Earth’s umbra and reflects on light sensitivity, aperture, and exposure time. Causes across earlier events: (1) Event 9 (audio) explicitly details the imaging settings—ISO 100, aperture 11, 25 ms—and says the contrast was too low to see the reddish part of the surface in shadow. The corresponding visuals show a partially lit moon without the reddish umbral detail, reinforcing the low-contrast outcome. (2) Event 4 (audio) explains that the Raspberry Pi camera cannot control the aperture and that its light sensor is clearly smaller than that of a standard camera; visually, the Pi camera module is shown up close. Those hardware constraints directly limit how exposure/aperture can be optimized for dim umbral detail. (3) Event 2 (audio) emphasizes the criticality of flange focal distance, notes the 20 mm spacer worked “best” but was “no perfect solution,” and the visuals show the “20mm” adapter and focus adjustment arrows—evidence of an improvised, suboptimal optical linkage that could degrade focus/contrast compared with a proper adapter. These three together plausibly lead to the failure reported in event 11. By contrast, event 14 (visual airplane crossing, audio about rotating the telescope) concerns tracking and scene orientation, not sensitivity/contrast required to capture the umbral surface, so it does not directly cause the failure.

question: In event 5, the narrator says the setup reaches an effective focal length of up to 2,700 mm. Which prior steps and constraints enabled this result? Select all that apply.
options: A: Connecting the camera module to a zoom lens (event 0) and mounting it—shown visually as a lens with a circuit board attached and described in the narration.
B: Using the Raspberry Pi camera’s smaller sensor (event 4), which the narrator later quantifies as yielding a large crop factor (~9).
C: Setting the correct flange focal distance with a 20 mm spacer (event 2), which allowed the sensor to sit at the right plane for focused images.
D: Accepting the mechanical clearance of a cheap tripod (event 3), which affects stability but not optical magnification.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 5 (audio), the narrator explains a crop factor of approximately nine that makes the zoom lens reach up to 2,700 mm effective focal length. Causes across earlier events: (1) Event 0 (audio) states he connected a camera module to a zoom lens to capture the event; visually we see the lens with a circuit board and wires mounted on a tripod—establishing the lens-camera coupling needed for any effective focal length. (2) Event 4 (audio) notes the Raspberry Pi camera uses a smaller light sensor; visually the Pi camera board is shown. This smaller sensor underlies the large crop factor the narrator cites in event 5, which directly inflates the effective focal length. (3) Event 2 (audio) details the importance of flange focal distance and reports that a 20 mm spacer worked best; visuals show the “20mm” adapter and focus arrows. Achieving the correct sensor-to-lens distance is necessary to realize focused images at the stated effective focal lengths. Event 3’s tripod clearance (audio and visuals) concerns stability/tracking, not the optical crop factor or focal length, so it does not enable the 2,700 mm figure.

question: Which earlier sub-events most directly enabled the later result where he says the target is “tracking it nicely” and he’s getting 90‑second subs to stack? (Choose all that apply)
options: A: Event 6 — After PEC training, he improves guiding to about 0.6 while carefully adjusting the rig outside.
B: Event 9 — He bypasses the Stellarium link by manually entering the comet’s coordinates in the framing tab on the PC.
C: Event 4 — He notes he likes the CEM 26 but wishes he’d chosen a sturdier tripod.
D: Event 3 — He introduces the session as Astro Boke and music plays while scenes transition.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 10, the audio explicitly says he put the target slightly left of frame, it’s “tracking it nicely,” and the 90‑second subs look good and will be stacked. Visually, a starry sky/comet effect overlays the room, reinforcing the imaging context. Causes: (A) Event 6’s audio details improved guiding (from ~0.9–1.2 down to ~0.6) and PEC training, while visually he’s outside fine‑tuning the rig—this directly supports smooth tracking needed for 90‑second subs. (B) Event 9’s audio explains he abandoned the Stellarium link and manually entered coordinates in NINA’s framing tab; visually he’s at the PC setup—accurate framing and target positioning are prerequisites for good subs. By contrast, (C) event 4 is a complaint about tripod sturdiness (not an enabling cause), and (D) event 3’s intro/music does not directly contribute to the technical outcome. Together, events 6 and 9 provide the necessary guiding performance and framing that lead to the later successful tracking and subs reported in event 10.

question: At the end, the video shows a close-up of a bright green comet. Which earlier actions most directly led to obtaining that comet image? (Choose all that apply)
options: A: Event 2 — He lays out the imaging plan and gear (CEM 26 mount, Z61, 2600MM Pro) and intends to shoot RGB.
B: Event 9 — He manually inputs the comet’s coordinates in NINA to frame the target after the Stellarium link fails.
C: Event 10 — He confirms it’s tracking nicely and that he is capturing 90‑second subs he will stack.
D: Event 5 — He finds polar alignment awkward and notes the mount shifts when tightening locks.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 12 visually presents the bright green comet close-up; the audio begins with him expressing excitement about capturing the target before transitioning into space‑evocative music. Causes: (A) Event 2’s audio enumerates his specific astrophotography equipment and plan to shoot RGB, while the visuals show him discussing beside a telescope—this gear choice and imaging plan enable the capture. (B) Event 9’s audio explains he manually entered coordinates in NINA when the Stellarium link failed, and visually he’s at the computer—accurate framing is essential for centering the comet. (C) Event 10’s audio confirms the target is “tracking nicely” with 90‑second subs he will stack, and the visual overlay of the starry sky indicates active imaging—these subs are the data from which the final comet image is produced. (D) Event 5 describes alignment difficulties (a hindrance rather than a cause), so it does not directly lead to the final successful comet image. Thus, the coordinated planning (2), precise framing (9), and successful acquisition of quality subs (10) culminate in the comet image shown in event 12.

question: In event 3, the presenter points to a diagonal trend on a graph and concludes the bursts are extragalactic due to dispersion. Which preceding sub-events most directly led to this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 1: Re-analysis of the 2001 Parkes data revealing a strange pattern in the waveform; the screen shows the dish and then a graph, while the speaker explains the data found years later.

B: Event 2: Observation of a narrow millisecond spike arriving earlier at higher frequencies and later at lower frequencies, contrasted against terrestrial interference that would be simultaneous across frequencies.
C: Event 0: The opening introduction that FRBs are mysterious millisecond radio flashes and hard to detect because of interference.
D: Event 1: The anecdote about local interference from a farmer’s car and microwave ovens that befuddled the telescope at the time.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 3): The presenter, on-screen with a complex graph showing a diagonal trend, explains in audio that radio waves traveling through plasma are dispersed so lower frequencies arrive later, and notes that as more telescopes found the phenomenon it became clear the burst was extragalactic. The direct precursors are: (A) Event 1’s re-examination of the 2001 Parkes data where, visually, the screen swaps from the dish to a waveform/graph, and in audio the speaker describes a peculiar pattern discovered years later—this sets up evidence beyond interference; and (B) Event 2’s explicit audio description of a millisecond spike that arrives earlier at high frequency and later at low, while the visual graph supports this frequency-time slope; the speaker contrasts this with terrestrial interference that would be simultaneous across frequencies. These two together establish the dispersion signature that implies an extragalactic path through plasma. Option C (event 0) is general background about FRB brevity and detection difficulty and does not by itself demonstrate dispersion or extragalactic origin. Option D (event 1’s interference anecdote) actually illustrates how local interference confused early searches, not the frequency-dependent delay that led to the extragalactic conclusion. Both audio explanations and the visual graphs across events 1–3 are needed to connect the pattern to intergalactic dispersion and the resulting conclusion.

question: Result sub-event (in event 3): Standing before an ancient Egyptian wall carving, the speaker concludes that ancient texts contain remarkable astronomical knowledge and claims the Anunnaki interbred with humanity, linking this theme to the biblical “sons of God” as “sons of the gods,” and that Sumerian tablets confirm an ancient race. Which earlier events/sub-events most plausibly served as the primary contributing factors leading to this conclusion? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 0: Against a starry backdrop, the speaker introduces ancient texts and traditions describing an advanced race or races—extraterrestrial beings who brought knowledge, referencing Sumerian texts/tablets.
B: Event 1: The speaker explains the tablets were found in what we now call Iraq and translated by multiple people (including Zechariah Sitchin), noting differing interpretations.

C: Event 2: The speaker elaborates on the Anunnaki from Sumerian tablets—“those who from heaven to earth came”—and cites cylinder seals and areas of text/evidence, while visuals shift to an ancient wall relief.
D: Event 5: The speaker, in front of a solar-system diagram, discusses Nibiru and a collision leading to the asteroid belt as per Sitchin’s translation.
gold_reasoning: The event 3 result sub-event is the speaker’s synthesized conclusion about advanced ancient knowledge, Anunnaki interbreeding with humanity, and the re-interpretation of “sons of God” as “sons of the gods,” all while visually framed by an ancient Egyptian wall carving that underscores the historical-textual argument. This conclusion is causally supported by a progression across events 0–2: (A) Event 0 audio introduces the idea of ancient texts describing extraterrestrial races bringing knowledge; visually, the starry backdrop ties the content to cosmic themes. (B) Event 1 audio establishes provenance and translation history of the tablets found in Iraq, citing multiple translators (including Sitchin) and differing interpretations; visually, the continued presentation stance reinforces ongoing scholarly discussion. (C) Event 2 audio defines the Anunnaki as “those who from heaven to earth came,” cites cylinder seals and textual evidence, deepening the evidentiary base; visually, the shift to an ancient relief emphasizes archaeological context. Together, these earlier events supply both the conceptual foundation (audio) and the historical/visual framing (visuals of cosmic backdrop and ancient reliefs) that lead to the event 3 conclusion. (D) Event 5’s Nibiru/asteroid-belt discussion, although thematically related to ancient interpretations, pivots to planetary mechanics and does not directly underpin the interbreeding/‘sons of the gods’ conclusion, making it a plausible but non-causal distractor.

question: In event 5, the PHD2 Log Viewer displays that dithers occurred and even shows how much it dithered each time. Which preceding setup steps most directly enabled those dithers to be issued and then appear in the log viewer? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: In PHD2, using the Tools menu to “Enable Server,” allowing acquisition software to send dither commands to PHD2.
B: Event 3: In Nebulosity 3, using the PHD Link to connect, set a dither, and move the telescope between frames before exposures.
C: Event 4: In Sequence Generator Pro’s Control Panel (Auto Guide tab), choosing PHD2 as the guiding interface and setting Medium Dither every frame so it handles dithering in the background.
D: Event 5: Commenting that the total error wasn’t great and that it’s a full moon at the moment.
gold_reasoning: The outcome in event 5 is the log viewer explicitly showing each dither’s magnitude. This requires that dithers were actually commanded and executed during guiding sessions. Event 2 (visual: PHD2 2.6.x interface; audio: the speaker says to go to the tools menu and click “enable server”) establishes that PHD2 can receive external dither commands—an essential prerequisite. Event 3 (visual: the Nebulosity 3 UI with a PHD Link; audio: the speaker explains connecting via the PHD link, setting a dither, and moving the scope) shows one acquisition workflow that actively triggers dithers between exposures. Event 4 (visual: SGP Control Panel Auto Guide tab set to PHD2 with “Medium Dither every 1 frame”; audio: he explains SGP connects to PHD2 and handles dithering in the background) shows another workflow that programmatically issues dithers before each frame. These configurations directly cause dithers to occur and be recorded, which is why event 5’s log viewer (visual: PHD2 Log Viewer graphs; audio: “while the tool takes an exposure in one space, it also dithers, showing by how much each time”) can display them. Option D is merely commentary in the same event about total error and the full moon; it does not enable or cause dithering to be logged.

question: In the moment when the speaker says the telescope is now fully collimated, which earlier sub-events most directly led to that successful collimation? Select all that apply.
options: A: Using a Bahtinov mask to center the focus pattern before imaging Saturn (earlier in event 9).
B: Demonstrating and employing the three front collimation screws with Bob’s Knobs on the OTA (event 2).
C: Defocusing on a bright star (Alpha Centauri) to view the concentric 'donut' and diagnose a slight collimation issue (event 6).
D: Identifying the thin side of the airy disc on-screen and turning the corresponding Bob’s Knob while chasing the star to center (event 7).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 8, the speaker audibly states it is "now all collimated," while the visuals show the active imaging software screen, indicating the collimation sequence has concluded. The direct causes span multiple earlier events and require both audio and visual cues to establish the chain. Event 2 (audio: discussion of the front of the OTA, "three collimation screws," and the benefit of "Bob’s Knobs" for easy tweaking in the dark; visual: close-ups of the front corrector area and hands demonstrating the knobs) sets up the method and hardware used for collimation. Event 6 (audio: "it's nighttime," setup on Alpha Centauri, and instruction to put the star out of focus to see the "donut" with a slight collimation issue; visual: laptop screen clearly showing the out-of-focus star donut and on-screen instructional text) provides the diagnostic step that reveals what needs correction. Event 7 (audio: the technique to cover/identify which screw corresponds to the thin side of the airy disc, then turning the appropriate Bob’s Knob while the star moves; visual: overlay text "TURNING COLLIMATION SCREW" and active adjustments at the telescope and on-screen star movement) is the corrective step that rectifies the misalignment. By contrast, option A (Bahtinov mask focus, event 9) is for focusing before imaging and occurs after collimation; it is not a direct cause of the collimation result declared in event 8.

question: When the speaker declares he is ready to image Saturn and later presents the final processed image with bright rings, which prior sub-events most directly enabled that outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Announcing that it’s the night of Saturn’s opposition and planning to collimate (event 1).
B: Completing collimation, confirmed by the speaker stating it’s now all collimated (event 8).
C: Focusing up with a Bahtinov mask and initiating an auto run with the motorized filter wheel to start recording (event 9).
D: Retrieving a beer from the fridge and noting the beer is not sponsored (event 10).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: Event 9 contains the audio declaration that he is "ready to image Saturn," and event 11 visually shows the final processed image of Saturn with on-screen credits, while the audio discusses the rings appearing vibrant. The causal chain requires both audio and visual evidence from at least three events. Event 1 (audio: explicitly states it is the night of Saturn’s opposition; visual: presenter by the scope) sets the timing context that later, in event 11 audio, is linked to the rings appearing vibrant due to light bouncing back—this opposition timing contributes to the bright ring appearance seen in the final visual image. Event 8 (audio: "now all collimated"; visual: the active setup/software) confirms the telescope is properly aligned, a prerequisite for sharp planetary data. Event 9 (audio: "I just need to focus up," mentions using a Bahtinov mask and then says he’s "ready to image Saturn," plus initiating an "auto run" with the motorized filter wheel; visual: the laptop interface and later Saturn on screen) captures the focusing and data-acquisition steps needed to produce material for the final processed image. Option D (getting a beer, event 10) is unrelated to imaging readiness or data capture/quality and thus does not directly enable the outcome.

question: In event 11, while the WHY IT MATTERS section and a solar system diagram are on-screen, the narrator quotes Penarrubia and concludes there should be “many more” interstellar objects than people have thought. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led to that conclusion, based on both the visuals and the narration across the video?
options: A: Event 0: The opening headline asserts a halo of 10 million interstellar objects around our solar system, as the narrator frames “interstellar objects” and “cosmic jetsam.”

B: Events 4–6: The text-and-voice explanation that interstellar rocks are briefly captured by the Sun and then slingshotted out again, so the Sun constantly captures and releases them, maintaining a rocky halo.
C: Event 10: The narrated recap of ‘Oumuamua and comet 2I/Borisov passing through on interstellar trajectories, with on-screen text quoting Pfeiarrubia predicting many more such objects.
D: Events 14–15: A discussion of JWST’s limitations and upcoming surveys (Gaia, Vera Rubin) that may find more comets.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 11): On-screen, the WHY IT MATTERS text and a solar system diagram appear while the narrator states that our system isn’t isolated and quotes Penarrubia saying there should be many more interstellar objects than people have thought. The causal chain is established by both visuals and narration across earlier events: (A) In event 0, the visual headline “OUR SOLAR SYSTEM MAY BE SURROUNDED BY A HALO OF 10 MILLION INTERSTELLAR OBJECTS” appears, and the narrator introduces interstellar objects and “cosmic jetsam,” seeding the overarching claim that many such bodies are present. (B) In events 4–6, the visuals show text describing how the Sun’s gravity temporarily captures interstellar rocks and then slingshots them out; the narration explicitly says the Sun constantly captures and releases these objects, maintaining a rocky halo and even noting their potential relation to the Oort Cloud. This mechanism explains why “many more” objects could accumulate around the system. (C) In event 10, the visuals and narration recount ‘Oumuamua and 2I/Borisov as interstellar visitors and include text attributing to Pfeiarrubia the prediction of many more such objects—observational support linked to the model. Together, these prior sub-events (headline hypothesis, dynamical mechanism, and observational examples) directly support the event 11 conclusion. (D) The JWST-and-surveys discussion (events 14–15) concerns future detection capability rather than the basis for the “many more” conclusion, so it is not a primary cause.

question: In event 16, the narrator argues that by measuring the orbits of many objects we can identify distinct populations—interstellar interlopers with different compositions versus homegrown comets. Which earlier sub-events most directly motivate and lead to that strategy, when considering both the on-screen text and the narration?
options: A: Event 12: The WHY IT MATTERS discussion explains that interstellar objects like ‘Oumuamua and Borisov reveal the chemical makeup and formation histories of other planetary systems.

B: Events 5–7: The capture-and-release/gravitational slingshot explanation shows a persistent rocky halo, implying a mix of interstellar debris near the Solar System that needs to be distinguished from native bodies.
C: Events 14–15: The surveys (Sloan, Catalina, Gaia, Vera Rubin) are described, and the narrator says we can distinguish homegrown versus interstellar comets by their paths and motions.
D: Event 8: The narrator states we lack the technology to detect these objects in big numbers yet, even though rare objects like ‘Oumuamua and Borisov have been seen.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 16): The narrator explicitly states that by measuring many orbits we can identify distinct populations and notes that objects trapped from the interstellar environment may have different compositions than Solar System comets. The visuals continue the text-heavy cosmic backdrop, and the audio foregrounds the composition difference and the orbit-measurement approach. The strongest causes are: (A) Event 12’s visuals and narration (WHY IT MATTERS) emphasize that interstellar objects reveal the chemical makeup and formation/evolution of other planetary systems, directly motivating the idea that composition-based differences exist and are worth identifying. (B) Events 5–7 visually outline, and the narration explains, the Sun’s capture-and-release dynamics that maintain a rocky halo around the Solar System; this implies a mixture of interstellar and native populations in the same space, creating the need to distinguish them. (C) Events 14–15 visually and verbally discuss survey programs (Sloan, Catalina, Gaia, Vera Rubin) and explicitly say we can tell homegrown from interstellar comets by their paths/motions—tying the strategy to concrete orbit measurements. (D) Event 8 is only about current detection limitations; while relevant context, it does not provide the causal rationale for why orbit measurements would reveal distinct, compositionally different populations, so it is not a primary cause.

question: In the closing (event 17), the narrator adds a caution that they are fully aware of false information surrounding the planet Nibiru. Which earlier segments most plausibly prompted this disclaimer by introducing the most controversial or extraordinary claims? Select ALL that apply.
options: A: Events 5, 12, and 13: Ancient artifacts and cuneiform visuals while the narrator attributes cosmic collisions from Sumerian/Babylonian texts (Enuma Elish) to Nibiru striking Tiamat and creating the asteroid belt, Earth, and Moon.

B: Events 6 and 7: Carlos Muñoz Ferrada’s predictions tied to Nibiru, with visuals of a newspaper headline and disaster scenes, and audio asserting near‑to‑the‑hour earthquake prediction accuracy and massive casualties.

C: Event 8: A green‑tinted phone scene and a newspaper about a “Mystery Heavenly Body,” while the narrator claims Nibiru will appear as a permanent second sun and that world events will intensify as it approaches.
D: Events 14–16: NASA/Caltech pages and animations about Planet Nine, with audio describing mass, orbit, and influence on dwarf planets, and analysis of orbits to infer an unseen planet.
correct_answer: Events 5, 12, and 13: Ancient artifacts and cuneiform visuals while the narrator attributes cosmic collisions from Sumerian/Babylonian texts (Enuma Elish) to Nibiru striking Tiamat and creating the asteroid belt, Earth, and Moon.

Events 6 and 7: Carlos Muñoz Ferrada’s predictions tied to Nibiru, with visuals of a newspaper headline and disaster scenes, and audio asserting near‑to‑the‑hour earthquake prediction accuracy and massive casualties.

Event 8: A green‑tinted phone scene and a newspaper about a “Mystery Heavenly Body,” while the narrator claims Nibiru will appear as a permanent second sun and that world events will intensify as it approaches.
gold_reasoning:
Result sub‑event (Event 17): Over dark electronic/ambient sounds, the narrator closes by saying they hope viewers enjoyed the evidence and that they are “fully aware of the false information… the planet Nibiru,” before the video ends with like/subscribe prompts. This is an explicit disclaimer about misinformation.
Preceding causes requiring both audio and visuals:
- Events 5, 12, 13 (audio+visual): The screen shows ancient reliefs, artifacts, and cuneiform tablets, and diagrams of Tiamat’s paths. The narration attributes dramatic celestial mechanics (Nibiru or its satellite striking Tiamat, forming the asteroid belt and even Earth and Moon) based on Sumerian/Babylonian narratives and “Stichin’s translations.” The combination of mythic visuals and extraordinary audio claims is precisely the type of content that could be labeled as “false information,” motivating a closing caveat.
- Events 6 and 7 (audio+visual): Visuals include a Spanish newspaper headline about visibility in 1999, solar‑system animations, destruction scenes, and a man on the phone. The narrator ties Carlos Muñoz Ferrada’s predictions to Nibiru, alleging near‑to‑the‑hour accuracy and immense death tolls. The extraordinary nature of these claims, paired with the suggestive imagery, heightens the need to acknowledge misinformation risks at the end.
- Event 8 (audio+visual): A green‑tinted phone call and a newspaper article “Possibly as Large as Jupiter Mystery Heavenly Body Discovered” accompany the assertion that Nibiru will become a permanent “second sun” and that world events will intensify before a comical sound effect. The sensational tone and imagery further justify the later disclaimer.
Why D is not a cause: Events 14–16 show NASA and Caltech pages/animations and provide measured audio about mass, orbital period, and inferred gravity—mainstream scientific content. Unlike the mythic collisions or dramatic prediction claims, this segment would not itself necessitate a warning about false information, so it is not a primary contributor to the closing disclaimer.

question: In event 9, the speaker re-connects his electronic boxes to a Vixen dovetail using 3D-printed clamps and glues the dew heater controller to his “power buddy.” Which earlier sub-events most directly led to this relocation and re-mounting choice? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2 — He explains the tube is no longer balanced properly after changes to the finderscope setup, showing the rig with more weight on one side.
B: Event 3 — He lays out a plan to move cables and electronics to balance weight and reduce leverage on the mount while pointing to the components on the rig.
C: Event 5 — He removes all cables/electronics from the tube and plans to shorten and re-solder them, shown while handling control boxes and connectors.
D: Event 1 — He discusses a fine-adjust mount that is very nice but incredibly heavy, noting the mount and finder together weigh about two kilograms.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 9): Audio explicitly states he is reconnecting the electronic boxes to a Vixen dovetail, with 3D-printed clamps and the dew heater controller glued to his Ascom-compliant relay controller. Visually, he is at the telescope reattaching gear. Causes: Event 2 (audio) details that the tube is no longer balanced and that the previous finderscope had been used to balance things; visually, the setup is cable-heavy. This imbalance is a direct motivator to shift where electronics are mounted. Event 3 (audio) gives his concrete plan to move cables/electronics to balance weight and reduce leverage on the mount; visually he points out the components he intends to relocate, directly foreshadowing the dovetail remount. Event 5 (audio) shows he actually removes the electronics and shortens cables, preparing them for a new mounting location; visually we see him working with the control boxes and connectors, enabling the later dovetail installation. By contrast, Event 1 (audio) about the heavy fine-adjust mount and the combined 2 kg with the finder is about overall mass, but does not itself specify relocating electronics to a dovetail; it is less directly causal for the specific re-mounting choice in event 9. The causal chain thus spans events 2→3→5 leading to the remounting action in event 9, supported by both spoken rationale and on-screen handling of the equipment.

question: In event 10, the result sub-event declares that Earth would become a “frozen, dark planet.” Which earlier events/sub-events most directly cause this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 8: The narration explains that a black hole with the Sun’s mass would exert the same gravitational pull at Earth’s distance, so Earth wouldn’t be sucked in and would keep orbiting—shown visually by orbital Earth views with sunrises/sunsets from space.

B: Event 1: The narration defines a black hole as a place from which even light cannot escape, while the visuals repeatedly show black holes with glowing rings against dark space, implying no sunlight would reach Earth.
C: Event 9: The narration details the consequences of losing the Sun’s light and heat—rapid cooling and disrupted photosynthesis—over visuals shifting from sunlit Earth scenes to black-hole imagery.
D: Event 6: The narration highlights the staggering size difference (a tiny black hole replacing the Sun) alongside visuals contrasting a small black object with a large star.
gold_reasoning: To infer why Earth becomes a “frozen, dark planet” in event 10, we need both the physics setup and the downstream consequences across multiple events. question: Result sub-event (Event 7): The narrator says the morning of September 12 might be your last chance to witness C/2023 P1 (Nishimura) before it’s engulfed by daylight. Which preceding sub-events most directly explain why visibility ends around that date? Select all that apply.

question: In event 7, the narrator states that the Earth and Moon orbit each other around their common center of gravity. Which earlier sub-events best explain why this is the case? Select all that apply.

B: Event 2 — Narration and visuals describing the Moon as a rock in a stable orbit around Earth due to motion and gravity.

Event 2 supplies the mechanism: visuals of the Moon and narration that it is in a stable orbit around Earth due to motion and gravity, i.e., gravitational attraction and orbital motion govern the system’s behavior. Event 9 reinforces the mass disparity and weaker lunar gravity (audio: “mass … 80 times less,” “gravity … 1/6”; visuals: astronauts moving on the Moon and Earth–Moon comparison), confirming the imbalance that leads both bodies to revolve around a shared center of mass rather than only one moving. Together, these audio-visual cues from events 2, 6, and 9 causally underpin the event 7 statement. Event 1’s stargazing anecdote is unrelated to barycenter dynamics.

question: In event 7, the presenter resolves the “date riddle” by stating that when the Sun enters Capricornus after sunset on January 14 (with on-screen times like “11:43 PM”), Makar Sankranti is celebrated the next day (January 15). The winter customs (event 5) and general orbit/solstice animation (event 2) provide background but do not directly cause the next-day celebration rule.

question: In event 8, a comparison graph of solar error appears while the narrator asserts that the Indian epicycle technique is twice as accurate as the Greek one. Which earlier sub-events most directly led to this conclusion and the decision to visualize that accuracy gap?

Event 12–13’s colonial/Wikipedia commentary is context about recognition, not a direct cause of the accuracy graph or claim, hence it is not correct.

question: In event 10, the narrator states that the AST/RO (“Astro”) telescope is being replaced by a new South Pole Telescope with enhanced capabilities. Which earlier sub-events most directly precipitated this replacement? Select all that apply.

question: Target result sub-event: In event 15, the speaker concludes it was a bad mistake not to involve parents when encouraging teenagers toward physics/astronomy (“Se nos olvida convencer a los padres también… esto es un error”). question: Result sub-event (Event 10): After saying he "wanted to hate this photo" to prove diffraction spikes "suck," the narrator sees his result and admits, "I'm not gonna lie, that's dope." In Event 10, before his reaction, the audio clearly states he aimed at a bright star away from the moon and used a 20-second exposure, while the visuals overlay the target name (Fomalhaut) and gear details. These conditions maximize a clean, bright star with visible spikes, directly enabling the impressive image that triggers his “that’s dope” reversal (C). question: Result sub-event (Event 7): The speaker says astronomers are trying to reduce diffraction spikes in the Giant Magellan Telescope design. Which earlier demonstrations/explanations most plausibly led to that engineering goal? Select all that apply.

In Event 3, both the visuals (laser and thin wire) and audio show that an obstruction yields a spike perpendicular to the obstruction—directly linking physical structures to spikes (A). Event 4 deepens this with visuals of diagrams and audio explanations that JWST’s mirror gaps and common spider struts produce spikes, while stars themselves are round, so the spikes are optical artifacts that can be engineered against (B). Event 5 provides the engineering context: audio explains refractors can’t scale, pushing designs toward reflectors with struts that unavoidably cause diffraction, and the visuals show the large-scale observatories this applies to—thereby motivating efforts to mitigate spikes in next-gen reflectors like GMT (C). Event 6 focuses on the human eye’s contribution to perceived spikes, which is informative but not a driver for structural telescope design choices; thus it doesn’t directly motivate GMT’s anti-spike design and is incorrect as a cause (D). Combining the audio explanations and visual demonstrations across Events 3–5 establishes the causal rationale for the Event 7 design goal.

question: Result sub-event: In event 16, the presenter shows images of Sirius A with its white dwarf companion (Sirius B) and audibly declares the lecture complete. question: Result sub-event: In event 10, after the narrator says "There we go," the BEFORE/AFTER split shows the bar scene becoming noticeably moodier. Which earlier steps most directly enabled that moodier AFTER look? Select all that apply.

- Why C (event 11) is not a direct cause: The haze step occurs later than event 10. options: A: Event 7: The speaker instructs deleting temporary files via Run by typing %TEMP%, then selecting all (Ctrl+A) and deleting, initiating a manual temp-file cleanup routine.
B: Event 4: The Disk Cleanup step where the speaker explains cleaning temporary and system files, visually showing Disk Cleanup options and starting the cleanup process.
C: Event 3: The Defragment and Optimize Drives step where the C: drive is analyzed and optimized to 0% fragmented.
D: Event 1: Changing the power plan from Balanced to High performance in Power Options.
gold_reasoning: To understand why the user in event 8 is about to delete Prefetch files, we need both what is said and what is shown across earlier steps. In event 7 (audio), the male speaker explicitly introduces "the next important step is temporary files delete," and details the method: open Run, type %TEMP%, press Ctrl+A, and delete. Visually in event 7, File Explorer opens the Temp folder, all items are selected, and a deletion is attempted (a pop-up shows some files are in use), establishing a manual clean-up workflow. In event 4 (audio), the speaker describes "disk cleanup," reassuring it targets temporary and unwanted files and advising to "clean up system files." Visually, Disk Cleanup windows are shown with temporary categories selected and the cleanup initiated. These two earlier actions (events 7 and 4) set a clear, tutorial-guided pattern of removing temporary/system junk, directly motivating the subsequent prefetch clean in event 8. In event 8 (visual), we see the Prefetch folder opened, all files selected, and the cursor hovering over Delete, which extends the same cleanup routine described earlier. By contrast, event 3 (defragment/optimize) is about disk fragmentation, not deleting cached files, and event 1 (power plan change) concerns power/performance profiles; neither directly contributes to deciding to delete Prefetch contents.

question: Result sub-event: The presenter right-clicks and chooses “save splits” and then “save layout” to prevent resets and preserve progress (event 9). Which earlier actions most plausibly made this saving necessary?
options: A: Adding four splits/segments for the Minecraft speedrun (Overworld, Nether, End Portal Search, Ender Dragon) (event 3).
B: Editing the layout by adding icons/components and customizing the timer display (event 4).
C: Creating a Window Capture in OBS so the audience can see LiveSplit (event 6).

gold_reasoning:
- Event 3 (audio+visual): He explains adding “four splits” and names them (Overworld, Nether, End Portal Search, Ender Dragon). On screen, large text overlays reflect these segments. These are split configurations that need to be preserved.
- Event 4 (audio+visual): He discusses editing the layout (icons, detailed timer, layout tweaks), while visually navigating layout options. These are layout changes that should be saved.
- Event 8 (audio+visual): He explains and demonstrates changing the background color and applying chroma key to get a transparent look; visually we see the background turn green and OBS filters mentioned. These are further layout-related settings worth preserving.
- Event 9 (audio): He explicitly instructs to “save splits” and “save layout” so LiveSplit doesn’t reset and progress/settings are maintained. The need to save is causally driven by the prior split definitions (event 3) and layout customizations (events 4 and 8). Both audio directions and on-screen changes across these events jointly show why saving at event 9 is necessary.

question: In event 6, the instructor formalizes and demonstrates a 16-beat strumming pattern with on-screen text showing “D--U--D--U--U--U--U” and emphasized counts “1 4 7 10 12 14 16,” gradually speeding it up to sound closer to the original. Which earlier sub-events most directly led to establishing this emphasized 16-stroke pattern?
options: A: Event 4: The instructor introduces a 16-stroke exercise (8 down, 8 up), insists not to skip or stress any stroke, plays all sixteen, and confirms the full count.
B: Event 5: He adds accented stresses on specific counts (1 and 4 first, then 7, later 10, 12, 14, 16) and suggests hitting the bass on stroke 1, demonstrating the feel.
C: Event 2: He contrasts open chords with bar chords and follows with a faster, rock-style riff after mentioning bar chords.
D: Event 3: He introduces a strumming pattern with timing guidance, demonstrating it at different speeds and giving advice on keeping time.
correct_answer: Event 4: The instructor introduces a 16-stroke exercise (8 down, 8 up), insists not to skip or stress any stroke, plays all sixteen, and confirms the full count.
Event 5: He adds accented stresses on specific counts (1 and 4 first, then 7, later 10, 12, 14, 16) and suggests hitting the bass on stroke 1, demonstrating the feel.
Event 3: He introduces a strumming pattern with timing guidance, demonstrating it at different speeds and giving advice on keeping time.
gold_reasoning: To understand why event 6 shows a codified 16-beat pattern with specific emphasized counts, we must synthesize both the spoken instruction (audio) and the on-screen/hand demonstrations (visual) across earlier events. In event 4 (audio), the instructor explicitly defines the foundation: a 16-stroke cycle (8 down, 8 up) and performs all 16 strokes (visual+audio), confirming the complete count. In event 5 (audio), he specifies which counts should be stressed—first 1 and 4, then adding 7, and later 10, 12, 14, and 16—and demonstrates these accents on the guitar, including the bass hit on stroke 1 (visual), directly mapping to the numbers that appear under the pattern in event 6. Event 3 further prepares the outcome by focusing on timing and demonstrating the same pattern at different speeds (audio+visual), which is exactly what happens again in event 6 when he starts slow and then increases speed to approach the original feel. The visible on-screen text and close-up strumming in event 6 require the viewer to combine the prior counting framework (event 4), the accent placements (event 5), and the timing/speed control (event 3) to see how these steps culminate in the displayed “D--U--D--U--U--U--U” with counts “1 4 7 10 12 14 16.” Event 2’s open vs bar chord contrast and rock-style riff are less directly tied to the exact 16-count emphasis mapping, making it a weaker cause.

question: In event 10, the instructor explains which strokes in the pattern belong to which chords while demonstrating on guitar. Which preceding sub-events most directly set up this chords-within-the-pattern mapping?
options: A: Event 7: He advises that switching chords within the pattern is needed to get closer to the original and discusses staying on one chord vs switching, then transitions to bar chords.
B: Event 6: He standardizes the 16-beat pattern with emphasized counts and demonstrates it toward the original feel, establishing the framework for assigning strokes.

D: Event 8: He focuses on bar-chord technique, demonstrating the same pattern with and without muting on E minor and repeating it slower for clarity.
correct_answer: Event 7: He advises that switching chords within the pattern is needed to get closer to the original and discusses staying on one chord vs switching, then transitions to bar chords.
Event 6: He standardizes the 16-beat pattern with emphasized counts and demonstrates it toward the original feel, establishing the framework for assigning strokes.
Event 9: He explains switching between two chords within a single pattern and demonstrates the upbeat rhythm before detailing how to attribute strokes.
gold_reasoning: Event 10’s result sub-event is the instructor audibly specifying which strums correspond to which chords while visually showing chord changes and strumming. This mapping relies on a multi-event buildup. Event 6 provides the underlying 16-beat framework with emphasized counts (audio) and shows him executing it (visual), giving a structure onto which chord ownership of strokes can be assigned. Event 7 then makes the causal bridge explicit (audio): he cautions that to approximate the original, one must switch chords inside the pattern rather than stay on one chord; this primes the viewer for chord attribution within the beat cycle, while his hands continue to demonstrate the idea (visual). Event 9 further narrows the focus by describing switching between two chords within a single pattern (audio) and immediately demonstrating it on the guitar with an upbeat rhythm (visual+audio), directly prefiguring the detailed attribution in event 10. Event 8, although a plausible precursor about bar-chord muting (audio) with accompanying demonstrations (visual), is not the direct setup for assigning specific strokes to different chords; it focuses on muting feel rather than the stroke-to-chord mapping emphasized in event 10.

question: Result sub-event: In event 10, after relaunching, the Minecraft main menu shows “3 mods loaded” and the “North’s Path Mod” is available. Which preceding actions most directly caused the mod to be recognized at startup? Select all that apply.

Second, in event 3 the browser is visibly on the Minecraft Forge site for 1.14.4, and the speaker instructs to choose and download the recommended installer (audio), which provides the Forge environment required for mods to load (B). Third, immediately before the main menu display in event 10, the speaker states (audio) that you “drop your mod into the mods folder” and then relaunch to check it, which is the direct action that makes the mod load on startup; visually, the subsequent main menu shows “3 mods loaded” and the mod information (C). Merely opening %appdata% and entering the “Minecraft Launcher” folder in event 7 (visual), without installing Forge or placing the mod JAR, does not directly cause the mod to be recognized at startup (D).

question: In event 12, the instructor shows the texture mapped successfully onto the cleaned geometry (original object hidden) after connecting the baked image to the Principled BSDF. (C) Event 8’s UVs. The audio notes enabling texture coordinates on re-import and confirms a “nice gridded UV map,” and visually the UV grid overlay is seen. (C) Events 3–4 show entry to Recovery (visuals of globe, macOS Utilities menu) while the narrator explains holding Command+R and possibly entering Wi‑Fi/admin credentials (audio), which is the gateway that allows access to Disk Utility and the reinstall workflow. Option D (event 2) is a plausible earlier attempt (audio: try Option-boot, visual: boot selector/error), but it failed and did not directly enable the reinstall-and-migrate chain that culminates in “Migration Complete.”

question: In event 10, the feed shows a misspelling being corrected and a #greenenergy tweet being favorited after the narrator explains that clicking Create launches a background process that runs every 15 minutes. Which preceding steps most directly caused those two bot actions to occur?
options: A: Event 6: Configuring Bot #1 to favorite tweets matching “#greenenergy …” and Bot #2 to publicly reply to misspellings (e.g., “accommodation”).
B: Event 5: Entering the Twitter API keys into the Bots form and clicking the “Create Twitter Bots” button to start the background process.

(2) In event 5, the visuals show the user pasting the Consumer Key/Secret and Access Token/Secret into the form and clicking “Create Twitter Bots,” and the audio explains they’re ready to create the bots—this launch step is tied to event 10’s audio that the Create button starts a recurring background process. Event 1 merely lists generic capabilities; without the concrete configs (event 6) and the create action (event 5), the specific actions in event 10 would not occur.

question: In event 8, the presenter confirms the code is working as intended and demonstrates that sections now align correctly beneath the sticky navigation after clicking links (result sub-event). Which preceding sub-events most directly enabled this correct alignment?
options: A: Event 7: Adds JavaScript that measures the .primary-navigation offsetHeight via querySelector and applies it to drive the scroll offset (e.g., via a custom property used for scroll-padding-top).
B: Event 6: Establishes a CSS custom property with a fallback for the scroll offset, enabling progressive enhancement that JS can improve upon.
C: Event 4: Demonstrates and adopts CSS scroll-padding-top (e.g., trying 300px) so that anchor jumps can be offset by padding rather than being hidden under the sticky nav.
D: Event 2: Adds scroll-behavior: smooth to HTML so the scrolling animation is nicer when navigating to sections.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 8): Visually, we see the split-screen with the code editor and the live page; clicking to a section now lands with the heading visible under the sticky nav. The speaker, in audio, explains using setProperty with a custom property (adds the missing "px" and fine-tunes by a pixel), then confirms it works as intended. The direct causes span multiple earlier events: • Event 7 (visual): We see JavaScript added in the editor that queries the primary navigation and reads offsetHeight; the audio mentions "navigation height," "query selector," and "offset height," showing that code is computing a dynamic value. This dynamic value is what drives the proper offset now, so A is required. • Event 6 (audio): The presenter discusses using variables (custom properties) with a fallback and calls this progressive enhancement—if JS is off, the fallback is used; with JS, the experience improves. This sets up the CSS to consume the value JS will provide, making B a contributing cause. • Event 4 (both): He explains scroll-padding-top conceptually and demonstrates it with a large value ("300 pixels" in audio), visibly creating space above the target sections. That establishes the mechanism (scroll-padding) that will be driven by the custom property/JS combination, hence C is also a primary factor. • By contrast, Event 2’s smooth scrolling (audio: "scroll-behavior: smooth") only affects animation, not the final alignment under the sticky nav; it does not cause the correct offset, so D is not a cause. question: In event 13, the presenter asks if you are getting close to 10 degrees of subcooling, indicating the charge is nearing target. Which earlier actions most directly caused the system to approach that subcooling?

question: In event 15, the presenter finishes testing (amp draws, thermostat cycling) and concludes, "you’re good to go." Which prior steps most directly enabled this final verification of proper operation?

question: In event 3, after selecting 4K, the camera displays a message that options are limited when the movie recording size is set to 4K. Which prior events most plausibly prompted the choice to switch to 4K that led to this limitation notice?
options: A: Event 1: The segment where the speaker discusses frame rate choices and transitions to mention 4K while showing the Movie rec. size menu.
B: Event 2: The explanation that 4K provides the best video resolution but has autofocus drawbacks, advising use in controlled studio setups.
C: Event 4: The Face Tracking AF demonstration with the screen indicating it will focus on faces.
D: Event 9: The 'Best Quality' segment emphasizing keeping ISO low (100–800) and avoiding ISO above 1600.
gold_reasoning: Establishing why 4K was selected (leading to the on-screen "options are limited" message in event 3) requires both audio and visual evidence from events 1–3. In event 1, the audio introduces frame rate choices and then mentions 4K, while the visuals show navigating the Movie recording size menu—this primes a shift toward selecting 4K. In event 2, the audio explicitly frames 4K as the best resolution but notes autofocus limitations and suggests it for studio use; this contextualizes why the speaker would choose 4K next to illustrate trade-offs. These two prior steps lead into event 3, where visuals show the 4K option being selected and the limitation message appearing. Event 4 occurs after the 4K selection and focuses on AF tracking, not the choice to enable 4K. Event 9 discusses ISO for image quality, which is unrelated to the decision to select 4K movie size.

question: In event 8, the command prompt shows the phone listed and the presenter proceeds to use ADB (enabling him to set install location). Which earlier actions most directly enabled this ADB recognition of the device? Select all that apply.
options: A: Unlocking Developer options by repeatedly tapping the Build number in Settings (event 3).
B: Turning on USB debugging and connecting the phone via USB, shown by the “USB debugging connected” notification (event 4).
C: Opening the Android platform-tools folder and running “ADB devices” from a command window there (event 7).
D: Moving an individual app like Clash of Clans to the SD card from its App info screen (event 2).
gold_reasoning: To get the device recognized in event 8, the presenter first had to enable Developer options (event 3), which is supported visually by tapping Build number until the on-screen message says he is already a developer, and by the audio guidance explaining how to unlock developer options. Next, he needed to enable USB debugging and physically connect the phone (event 4). Visually we see the Developer options screen and the status bar notification “USB debugging connected,” while the audio explicitly instructs plugging in the phone and references USB debugging. Finally, he had to actually execute ADB from the correct location (event 7), where the audio tells us to Shift+right-click in platform-tools and type “ADB devices,” and visually we see him navigating to and opening the command window. These steps directly lead to event 8 where the command prompt lists the device (visual) and the presenter explains what to do if it shows as unauthorized and discusses setting install location (audio). Simply moving a single app like Clash of Clans in event 2 (visual) does not cause the device to be recognized by ADB, so D is not a causal prerequisite.

question: In event 4, the right phone shows “Transferred successfully” while the left shows “Erfolgreich gesendet,” and the user taps “Done.” Which preceding steps most directly enabled this transfer completion?
options: A: Event 1: Opening the Mi Mover (Daten verschieben) app and setting the device as the sender.
B: Event 2: Scanning the QR code and connecting the new device to the old phone’s hotspot (MiMover_7F7F7F / identified as Redmi Note 10 Pro), linking both phones.
C: Event 3: Choosing 9.67GB of content (pictures, messages/contacts, audio/video/documents, system app data, third‑party apps) to transfer.
D: Event 7: Rearranging icons and searching for the Phone/SMS apps after the transfer.
gold_reasoning: Visual evidence: Event 1 shows the user navigating to “Daten verschieben” with on‑screen options for sender/receiver; Event 2 shows the QR code scan and connection to the hotspot named “MiMover_7F7F7F” with prompts like “Mit dem neuen Gerät verbinden”; Event 3 displays “Ausgewählt: 9.67GB” with categories (Bilder, Nachrichten/Kontakte/Anrufe, Audio/Video/Dokumente, System‑App‑Daten, Drittanbieter‑Apps) selected; Event 4 shows both phones on “Senden…” and “Receiving…” screens progressing to “Erfolgreich gesendet/Transferred successfully.” Audio evidence: In Event 1, the speaker states he’s using the Mi Mover/Daten verschieben app and designates himself as the sender; in Event 2, he explains agreeing to conditions, using the QR code, connecting via hotspot to the Redmi Note 10 Pro, and says they can start; in Event 3, he mentions checking and moving apps, settings, pictures, messages, contacts; in Event 4, he says it’s now sending/receiving and later confirms the transfer is complete. These steps (A, B, C) collectively cause the successful state in Event 4. Option D occurs after completion and does not enable the transfer.

question: In event 6, the receiver phone shows transferred photos in the Photos app and the music app begins indexing with songs present. Which earlier actions most directly led to photos and music appearing on the new device?
options: A: Event 3: Selecting transfer categories that include “Bilder” and “Audio, Video und Dokumente,” along with relevant apps, totaling 9.67GB.
B: Event 4: Completing the transfer, with both phones showing success messages and the user tapping “Done.”
C: Event 2: Linking devices by scanning the QR code and connecting to the sender’s hotspot to establish the transfer channel.
D: Event 0: Showing the TECHVIEW intro screen and initial general phone interactions.
gold_reasoning: Visual evidence: Event 3 shows “Ausgewählt: 9.67GB” with categories explicitly including Bilder (pictures) and Audio/Video/Dokumente; Event 2 shows the QR scan and hotspot connection that technically links the devices for transfer; Event 4 visually confirms the transfer progression and final success on both phones; Event 6 shows the user opening Photos on both devices (grid/albums visible) and then Spotify, where playlists appear and the app indexes content on the new phone. Audio evidence: In Event 3, the speaker talks about moving applications, settings, pictures, and more; in Event 2, he describes connecting via hotspot and says they can start; in Event 4, he states it’s sending/receiving and later that the transfer is complete; in Event 6, he confirms that while not all photos came over, some did, and that the music copied and is being indexed. Therefore, the category selection (A) plus successful completion (B) enabled by the established connection (C) caused the photos and music to appear in Event 6. The TECHVIEW intro in Event 0 is unrelated.

question: In event 9, the stream shows the ON AIR indicator with the Warzone title screen and a facecam overlay, meaning the broadcast is live on Twitch. Which prior steps most directly enabled this live status to occur?
options: A: Event 5: Adjusting the stream resolution to 720p to minimize buffering for viewers.
B: Event 2: Signing in to Twitch via QR/website, passing CAPTCHA, and completing two-factor authentication to link the account.
C: Event 3: Entering the activation code and receiving confirmation that the PSN/SEN account is linked to the Twitch account, then selecting Twitch as the broadcast service.
D: Event 7: Using the Broadcast Gameplay screen (with title/quality set and invite/share options) to initiate the Twitch broadcast from PlayStation.
gold_reasoning:
- Result sub-event (event 9): Visually, the gameplay screen shows ON AIR and a facecam overlay while on the Warzone title screen; audibly, the presenter states, "This is actually streaming to Twitch right now," confirming the live state.
- Causes across earlier events require both modalities:
  • Event 2 (audio+visual): The presenter explains signing in via QR/website, logging into a (test) Twitch account, passing CAPTCHA, and using two-factor authentication; visually we see the PS4 sign-in prompt, QR code page, Twitch login, CAPTCHA, and 6‑digit code verification. These steps link the Twitch account credentials needed for broadcasting.
  • Event 3 (audio+visual): We see the activation code page and then the PS4 confirmation screen: "Your SEN account is now linked to your Twitch account: chowibplaytest" with OK/Sign Out options. The speaker says they’ve linked and are selecting Twitch, then moving to stream settings—completing the platform linkage required before going live.
  • Event 7 (audio+visual): The Broadcast Gameplay screen is shown with Start Broadcasting alongside invite/share options; the speaker discusses inviting friends and sharing the link. This is the interface from which the live broadcast is initiated after settings are configured, leading directly to the ON AIR status seen in event 9.
- Why A is not sufficient: Event 5’s visual and audio discussion about choosing 720p concerns viewer experience (buffering) but does not by itself enable the stream to go live. The live status specifically depends on successful account linking (events 2–3) and initiating the broadcast from the Broadcast Gameplay screen (event 7), evidenced by both the on-screen confirmations and narrated instructions.

question: In event 10, after the presenter stops the stream, he notes the gameplay has returned to full resolution. Which earlier settings/actions most directly caused the gameplay area to be reduced during the broadcast?
options: A: Event 4: Enabling "Display Message to Spectators and Spectators' Comments" in Broadcast Gameplay (which the speaker warns will shrink the gameplay window).
B: Event 6: Keeping the spectator message/comment display checkbox enabled on the Broadcast Gameplay screen just before starting.
C: Event 9: Going live ON AIR with the overlay and comment area visible while on the Warzone title screen.
D: Event 1: Launching Warzone and pressing X to start.
gold_reasoning:
- Result sub-event (event 10): Audibly, the presenter says he has stopped broadcasting ("I'm no longer broadcasting") and notes the screen has returned to full resolution; visually, the broadcast UI disappears and the gameplay fills the screen.
- Causes across earlier events require both modalities:
  • Event 4 (audio+visual): On the Broadcast Gameplay settings screen, the speaker discusses the option to display spectator messages and explicitly warns that it reduces the gameplay window; visually, that option is shown in the interface as part of the settings.
  • Event 6 (visual): Immediately before starting, the Broadcast Gameplay screen shows the "Display messages to spectators" option checked, confirming that the reduced-window layout will be applied when live.
  • Event 9 (audio+visual): The stream is ON AIR with a facecam/comment overlay; the audio mentions wanting to read comments and suggests using another device for chat, while visually the live overlay/comment area is present, evidencing that the gameplay window is indeed reduced during the broadcast.
- Therefore, the reduced gameplay area during the live stream is caused by enabling spectator messages (events 4 and 6) and then actually being live with that overlay active (event 9). Stopping the broadcast in event 10 removes the overlay, restoring full resolution.
- Why D is incorrect: Launching Warzone (event 1) is unrelated to the UI layout change; it does not affect the gameplay window size during streaming.

question: In the segment where the side-by-side view labels the enhanced result as “MicroVariationNoiseMap” and the grass surface shows darker patches breaking up repetition, which earlier steps most directly enabled that outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: Introduced micro variation by tiling the grass texture at a different scale using a Texture Coordinate multiplied by a scalar parameter (default set to 0.5).
B: Event 4: Built a macro-variation-driven blend using T_macro variation with tiling control and a Lerp fed by a texture channel to blend micro colors.
C: Event 6 (earlier in the same segment): Added macro variation noise, created a “noise contrast” scalar to control it, and multiplied this result into the base color before comparing results.
D: Event 7: Set up a long strip of landscape and remarked it’s still tiled on large environments.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In Event 6, the visual shows a split view culminating in a labeled “MicroVariationNoiseMap,” with the grass preview exhibiting darker patches and more varied breakup. The audio in Event 6 explains adding macro variation noise, introducing a “noise contrast” parameter, wiring it into a Lerp and multiplying it into everything feeding the base color before comparing results—this directly causes the darker patch breakup and the labeled comparison (visual + audio). However, this effect builds on earlier steps: In Event 2, the speaker (audio) details adding micro variation via a Texture Coordinate multiplied by a scalar defaulting to 0.5; visually, the material graph and previews are shown side-by-side, establishing the foundational micro tiling difference used later. In Event 4, the audio describes creating a macro-variation-based blend using T_macro variation, tiling control, and a Lerp driven by a texture channel; visually, we see node additions in the graph consistent with this blend logic. These earlier blends and tiling controls set the stage for Event 6’s noise to have something meaningful to multiply into, producing the final MicroVariationNoiseMap comparison. Event 7’s long landscape demonstration is observational and follows after these steps; it does not directly cause the MicroVariationNoiseMap outcome.

question: Later, a smooth near-to-far blend is demonstrated where close areas are treated differently from distant areas (described as black near, white far) and the result is applied to another landscape. Which prior actions most directly enabled that distance-based gradient blend to function and be visible in the scene? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 8: Created a distance-based gradient by adding Pixel Depth, Subtract, Divide, and Clamp nodes, organizing them into a comment (the “Create Gradient Far From Camera” logic).

B: Event 9 (earlier in the same segment): Wired a new Lerp with the near-group into A and far-group into B, used the gradient as Alpha, inserted this before the noise multiply, then saved and applied a material instance to the second landscape.

C: Event 6: Established the macro variation noise path and “noise contrast,” into which the near/far Lerp result is multiplied, making the distance effect clearly visible when inserted into the multiply chain.
D: Event 5: Simply plugged the microcolor and microcolor variation into the base color and saved the material.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In Event 9, the audio states “close to the camera, the color is black, further away it’s white,” and explains wiring a new Lerp (near group to A, far group to B) with the gradient as Alpha, then placing the result into the multiply that adds noise, saving, creating an instance, and applying it to a second landscape. Visually, we see the material graph with complex node networks and the landscape preview updating, including a scene with grass (and snow area), confirming the distance-based blend working. This outcome depends on: (A) Event 8, where the audio describes building the gradient using Pixel Depth, Subtract, Divide, and Clamp, and organizing it into a comment; visually we see the graph edits and grouping, which provides the actual near–far mask that drives the blend. (B) Event 9’s earlier sub-steps wire that mask into a new Lerp combining the near and far groups and place the Lerp’s result into the noise multiply, then apply the instance—audio details the steps and visual previews corroborate the change on the landscape. (C) Event 6 provided the macro variation noise path (audio: creating “noise contrast,” multiplying into base color), which is exactly where Event 9 inserts the distance-blended result (“place the result of the Lerp in the B input of the multiply to add noise”), making the near/far effect visible. Event 5’s earlier microcolor-to-base-color hookup is not the mechanism enabling the distance-driven blend and thus is not a direct cause of the demonstrated gradient-based result.

question: Result sub-event: In event 13, the presenter says “boom” as the overall layout sketch is finished and declares they’re going with the minimalist layer style. Considering both what is spoken and what appears on-screen earlier, which prior sub-events most directly set up and led to that outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 4: The speaker instructs listing needed info and forming a storyline (audio) while the notebook visually shows items and a BEGINNING–MIDDLE–END diagram with “PROBLEM” circled.
B: Event 5: The content is organized into BEGINNING/MIDDLE/END on the notebook (visual) and on-screen text reads “TIP #3 PICK A LAYOUT TYPE” while the speaker explains the third tip (audio).
C: Event 9: The speaker introduces Tip #4—develop a layout style—audibly listing “the minimalist, the background bleed, and the color combo,” with on-screen text showing those style names.
D: Event 1: The humorous bit about insecurities, a shriek, and glass shattering before saying, “Anyways that’s beside the point.”
gold_reasoning: To reach the result in event 13 (the sketch is completed and the minimalist layer style is chosen), the video builds prerequisites across multiple earlier events using both visuals and narration. In event 4 (audio), the presenter explains listing the information and developing a storyline; visually, we see the notebook and a BEGINNING–MIDDLE–END flow with a circled “PROBLEM,” establishing what content must go into the layout. In event 5, the visuals again show the notebook sections and on-screen “TIP #3 PICK A LAYOUT TYPE,” while the audio states the third tip is selecting a layout type—this step transitions from what to include into how to arrange it. In event 9, the speaker explicitly opens Tip #4 (audio) and names the style options—“minimalist, background bleed, color combo”—with matching on-screen text; he even notes a preference for minimalist, directly informing the later decision. These combined steps (events 4, 5, 9) provide the content, structure, and stylistic direction necessary for event 13’s result: the rough overall layout sketch being finished and the commitment to the minimalist style. Event 1’s jokes (audio) and comedic sounds don’t provide structural or stylistic instructions, so they are not causal.

question: Result sub-event: In event 12, slides titled “COLOR COMBO” appear while the speaker explains that a theme color ties all elements together. Which prior sub-events most plausibly caused or led to this segment, based on both narration and on-screen visuals? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 9: The speaker launches Tip #4 on layout styles, audibly listing “the minimalist, the background bleed, and the color combo,” while on-screen text displays those style names.

B: Event 10: After describing the minimalist style on a slide (visual), the speaker transitions (audio) to introducing “background bleed,” advancing the sequential coverage of styles toward color combo.

gold_reasoning: Event 12’s COLOR COMBO segment follows a clearly narrated and visually signposted sequence.
