Event 10 shows the MINIMALIST slide (visual) and the speaker transitions (audio) into introducing “background bleed,” signaling a stepwise progression through the styles. Event 11 reinforces this sequence by featuring BACKGROUND BLEED slides (visual) while the speaker says he’ll move on to “color combo” next (audio), even joking about the names. Together, these earlier sub-events set the expectation and order that culminate in event 12’s COLOR COMBO slides and explanation. Event 6 concerns “THE GRID,” a layout type from a different tip (layout types, not layer styles), so it doesn’t cause the COLOR COMBO segment.

question: In event 8, the man walks to the gray couch and puts his hands on his head, visibly stressed. Which preceding sub-events most directly contributed to this stressed reaction?
options: A: Event 5 (audio): He describes the toll of balancing a full-time programming job with intensive data structures/algorithms prep, saying it harmed his quality of life and questioning the purpose of technical interviews.
B: Event 7 (audio): He recounts job-search and interview exhaustion, including studying through the holidays and feeling he never wanted to do another technical interview again.
C: Event 8 (audio, earlier in the segment): He talks about reaching final interview rounds only to be rejected with vague feedback, describing the defeat and double standards in tech.
D: Event 0 (visual/audio): The intro frames coding as valuable with FAANG logos and mentions common perks, making the industry seem attractive.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 8 (visual), the man moves to the couch and places his hands on his head, a clear nonverbal cue of frustration/stress. The immediate audio context in event 8 describes being rejected after final rounds and receiving vague feedback, directly tying that visual stress reaction to the fresh rejection (audio in 8 → visual in 8). This acute disappointment builds on earlier pressures: in event 5 (audio), he details how interview prep on top of a full-time coding job damaged his quality of life, and in event 7 (audio), he further describes interview/job-search exhaustion, including studying through the holidays and feeling burnt out by the process. Visuals in events 5 and 7 show him actively working/gesturing in a focused setup, reinforcing the workload backdrop, but the key causal content comes from the audio. Together, these at-least-three events (5, 7, and 8) form a causal chain from prolonged interview-related strain and fatigue to the immediate rejection, culminating in the stressed body language on the couch in event 8. Event 0’s intro about perks and industry appeal does not directly precipitate the acute stress reaction, making it a plausible but ultimately incorrect distractor.

question: Result sub-event: In event 12, the speaker says they keep getting requests to compare CTR and average duration with similar channels, asks viewers to stay tuned, and invites feedback. Which earlier moments most plausibly contributed to this product direction? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 9: On-screen text asks “#3 Why focus on AVD instead of average percentage viewed?” while the speaker cites viewer feedback that comparing average duration across different video lengths is unfair and explains discovery uses both relative and absolute watch time.
B: Event 7: The speaker discusses different ranking models across platforms and says external traffic does not negatively affect discovery.

C: Event 3: Overlays appear (“#1 Views are up but CTR is down” and “#2 Views are up but watch time is down”) while the speakers stress CTR and AVD aren’t the whole picture and ask for further explanation, highlighting metric confusion.
D: Event 4: The striped-shirt speaker calls CTR a paradox, advises looking at CTR with impressions, and says a new feature from Patricia will call that out—aimed at helping interpret performance.
gold_reasoning: Event 12’s announcement (audio: they are receiving requests to compare CTR and average duration with similar channels; visual: orange-shirt speaker addressing viewers) is best understood as a response to earlier metric confusion and user feedback. In event 9, the visual prompt “#3 Why focus on AVD…” and the audio explicitly mention viewer feedback about fairness when comparing average duration across different lengths, and the speaker clarifies that discovery accounts for both relative and absolute watch time—this directly motivates cross-channel comparisons. Event 3 visually lists common concerns (“#1… CTR is down”, “#2… watch time is down”) while the audio notes CTR/AVD aren’t the entire picture and seeks more explanation, evidencing widespread confusion. Event 4’s audio labels CTR a paradox and recommends pairing CTR with impressions, while visually the striped-shirt speaker emphasizes guidance—these underscore the need for clearer comparative metrics. Event 7, although informative about external traffic and ranking models, does not address comparing metrics with similar channels, so it is not a primary driver of the result in event 12.

question: In event 7, the speaker concludes her example by expressing enthusiasm and readiness to take on the challenge, thanking the interviewer. Which prior sub-events formed the immediate build-up that caused this closing declaration within the sample answer? Select all that apply.

This capstone is causally built by earlier parts of the sample answer. Together, these steps lead directly to the enthusiastic, thankful finish in event 7. Event 8’s book promotion (visual of the book, audio about availability and shipping) is a separate segment after the sample answer and does not contribute to the event 7 conclusion.

question: In the result sub-event where the narrator loads Craigslist while using Tor and says it will be difficult to identify where he is because he has a unique IP (event 5), which prior events directly enabled this outcome? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Launching Tor and connecting via the Vidalia Control Panel, then opening the Tor Browser to the Tor check page, as shown when it begins connecting and loads check.torproject.org.
B: Viewing the Craigslist directory in the earlier standard browser session (non‑Tor).
C: Seeing the Tor "Congratulations. Your browser is configured to use Tor" page showing a new apparent IP address.
D: Subscribing to blocklists and blocking IPs using PeerBlock.
gold_reasoning:
- Event 3 (visual): We see the cursor open Tor via the Vidalia Control Panel and the Tor Browser showing "Connecting..." to check.torproject.org, confirming the process of joining the Tor network. Event 3 (audio): The narrator explains Tor reroutes traffic through multiple computers, yielding a unique proxy IP that obscures the user's identity and location. These visuals and narration establish the technical step that makes anonymity possible.
- Event 4 (visual): The Tor check page displays "Congratulations. Your browser is configured to use Tor" and shows an apparent IP address, confirming Tor is active. Event 4 (audio): He notes Tor also won’t store history/cookies once closed, reinforcing that the Tor session is isolated.
- Event 5 (visual): After the confirmation, the browser loads Craigslist. Event 5 (audio): The narrator explicitly says Tor gives him a unique IP so it will be hard to find where he is, tying the confirmed Tor configuration to the anonymous Craigslist access.
- Option B (event 1) is a non‑Tor browsing step and does not enable anonymity. Option D (event 6) concerns PeerBlock’s filtering and is unrelated to achieving a Tor-based unique IP for Craigslist. Therefore, the direct enablers are the Tor connection/setup (A) and the confirmation of Tor being active with a new IP (C).

question: In event 2, the Ponify extension ends up enabled in Chrome’s Extensions manager. Which preceding sub-events most directly led to this result? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 2: He confirms the Chrome install prompt and clicks the Install button for Ponify.
B: Event 0: He announces there are Firefox and Chrome extensions and says he’ll show how to use them, setting the plan to install.
C: Event 1: He introduces a basic features demo after suggesting viewers read about the Brony phenomenon, signaling an imminent walkthrough.

gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 2): The Chrome Extensions page shows Ponify enabled (vision), and the narrator says it has installed and he’ll demonstrate features (audio). The direct causal chain spans multiple earlier events. In event 2 itself, just before the enabled state, we see and hear him confirm and click Install on the extension dialog (vision: install dialog; audio: he explains confirming and installing), which is the immediate cause. In event 1 (audio: he introduces a forthcoming demo; vision: the “WHAT IS BRONY?” interlude returning to the browser), he signals an imminent walkthrough that motivates actually proceeding with installation. Event 4 (Preferences/Highlighting) occurs later and does not cause the extension to be enabled.

question: Result sub-event: In the USB drive’s Kodi directory, a folder named “portable_data” appears populated with subfolders (addons, cache, userdata, etc.) and is then managed (deleted/copied) later (event 6). Which earlier steps most directly caused this portable_data folder to be created on the USB drive? Select all that apply.
options: A: Adding a space and “-p” to the Kodi.exe shortcut that targets the USB install to make Kodi run in portable mode (event 3).
B: Launching/opening Kodi once after setting up the portable shortcut, which triggers creation of the portable profile/folder (event 4, followed by the Kodi UI in event 5).
C: Installing Kodi onto the USB drive by selecting it as the destination during setup and completing the installer (events 0–2).
D: Changing the skin background image inside Kodi’s Appearance settings (event 7).
gold_reasoning: The portable_data folder visible on the USB (event 6, visual: the USB “Kodi/portable_data” with subfolders; audio: instructions about putting a build into the portable data folder) results from a chain across earlier events. First, Kodi must be installed to the USB (events 0–2). We see the user choose the USB drive as the destination during setup (event 0 visual) and the extraction/installation completes (event 1 visual; audio instructs to proceed and wait). The setup then offers “Run Kodi,” and the user clicks Finish (event 2 visual; audio: “run Kodi,” “click finish”), establishing that the install is complete on the USB. Next, to make Kodi generate portable data on the USB rather than the default location, the shortcut is configured with a space then “-p” (event 3 audio explicitly says “space and then dash P to make it portable,” while the visuals show creating a shortcut targeting Kodi.exe on the USB). Finally, the speaker explains you should open it once so that the portable data is created (event 4 audio: open it once creates portable data; event 4 visual shows the Kodi splash, and event 5 shows Kodi running). These steps (A, B, C) together directly cause the portable_data folder to be created on the USB, which we later see in event 6. Changing the skin background (D, event 7) is unrelated to creating the portable_data directory.

question: Result sub-event: Kodi later shows a customized screen with the “Game of Ohms” channel and related content (event 9). Which prior actions most directly enabled this customized build/content to appear within Kodi from the USB-based setup? Select all that apply.
options: A: Copying the “Fresh Copy” build into the USB’s Kodi/portable_data folder so addons/settings are present for the portable profile (events 6–7).
B: Creating and using a portable shortcut (adding “-p” and then launching it) so Kodi loads its profile from the USB drive (events 3–4).
C: Installing Kodi onto the USB drive and completing the setup process so Kodi can run from the USB (events 0–2).
D: Right‑clicking the portable_data folder and choosing Open in File Explorer (event 8).
gold_reasoning: The appearance of the “Game of Ohms” channel screen within Kodi (event 9 visual) reflects that a customized build/addons were in place and being loaded from the USB-based profile. Earlier, the video shows copying a “Fresh Copy” into the portable_data folder on the USB (events 6–7 visuals: delete then copy progress; audio in event 6 explains putting the build into the portable data folder; event 7 audio: storage considerations, “actually it’s working,” and that moving the build to a portable location fixes issues and works for other builds). That step (A) provides the actual content/configuration needed for the custom screen. For Kodi to load that content from the USB profile, it must run in portable mode, which is established by adding a space and “-p” to the shortcut and then launching it (events 3–4: audio explicitly instructs “space and then dash P to make it portable,” and to open it once; visuals show creating the shortcut and Kodi launching). Finally, this all depends on Kodi having been installed to and runnable from the USB in the first place, which we see through the installation and completion steps (events 0–2: visuals of setup destination selection and file extraction; audio: instructions to finish and run Kodi). Simply opening the portable_data folder in File Explorer (D, event 8) does not itself cause the customized channel to appear inside Kodi.

question: In event 8, the presenter asserts (in audio) that most English words have Latin or French roots while a pie chart of word origins is shown on screen. Based on both visuals and narration across the lecture, which earlier sub-events most directly led to this outcome?

Event 6 reinforces this with a ‘02 LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT’ visual and a map, while the audio specifies that Anglo-French became the official language and that elites spoke French and others spoke Old English—establishing the social-linguistic conditions for borrowing. Event 7 then makes the mechanism explicit both visually and verbally: the on-screen formula “Old English + French = Middle English” and the audio example (‘mansion’) directly explain how French vocabulary entered English. Together, these three events causally lead to the event 8 conclusion and pie chart. Event 9, although plausible thematically, focuses on Crusade-driven schooling (vision: classroom/battle imagery; audio: schools/colleges) and does not directly explain the lexical roots, so it is not a primary cause of the event 8 claim.

question: In event 12, the narrator states that London became the main educational hub of England (while London landmark visuals appear) before transitioning to “04 LITERARY WORKS.” Which prior sub-events most plausibly caused this development, as evidenced by both what is shown and what is said?

question: In event 10, a result sub-event occurs where the speaker explicitly urges graduate students to start conversations about open research and to “let them know this is something you care about.” Which earlier sub-events most plausibly drove this call to action?

question: In event 6, the speaker makes a clarifying statement: “I’m not a communist… nobody is saying publishing is free.” Which earlier sub-events most directly led to this clarification about costs and what open access advocates are actually proposing?

Event 3 contributes systemic cost evidence: the visual graph showing prices far outpacing inflation and labeled stacks with multi-thousand-dollar disciplines, and the audio critique that journals don’t employ the producers of content—together justifying a discussion focused on cost reform rather than “everything free.” Event 2 adds broader context: visuals of digitization paired with a librarian being handed an expensive bill, while the audio calls the pricing situation “the theater of the absurd,” reinforcing the monetary distortions prompting the speaker’s careful distinction in event 6. In contrast, event 1’s description of a functioning historical model doesn’t directly drive the need to preempt the “communist” straw man; it lacks the acute cost/abuse triggers that motivate the clarification.

question: In event 8, a tire is drawn beside a brick wall while the speaker explains how a “no” answer may show up (e.g., a flat tire or rejection). Which prior sub-events most directly set up this outcome?

question: What earlier sub-events most directly caused the result sub-event where the “Top US Marginal Tax Rate” graph appears and the narrator begins explaining changes since 1913 (result sub-event in Event 8)? Select all that apply.

Event 3 adds the historical-economic context: the screen visually shows “Revenue Acts of 1861 & 1862” while the audio explains graduated taxes and problems with tariffs, priming the need for a modern federal income tax whose rates could be historically charted. Event 6 contributes the political-ratification mechanism: the audio cites the two-thirds of Congress/three-fourths of states thresholds and mentions key figures, signaling how the income tax became actionable nationwide; the visual of the animated lecturer supports the moment. Event 11 is a distractor: its visuals (cat close-up) and audio (subscribe/outro and objections chatter) occur well after the graph segment and do not set it up.

options: A: Event 4: The speaker lists populists/Greenback/Democrats under W.J. Bryan/Socialists/labor calling for a 2% income tax in 1894, then hints someone would have a problem and calls for a Supreme Court case, with upbeat music and a cash-register sound.

Farmers’ Loan & Trust and on-screen text explicitly states that income from property was deemed a direct, unconstitutional tax requiring apportionment. question: In event 7, the doctor turns to specific diagnostic tests for ringworm (visual diagnosis, skin scraping under a microscope, KOH mount, culture, biopsy). Which earlier sub-events most plausibly prompted this focus on diagnostic testing?

question: In event 7, the result sub-event is the narrator concluding "beyond that, we don't really know anything" about Proto-World while a bubble lists only rudimentary features like "Consonants Vowels 10-100 Phonemes." question: In event 9, the result sub-event shows the orange character in the patient’s thought bubble changing from distressed (bandaged head) to smiling as the session progresses, implying relief after bringing something to awareness. (D) Event 4 focuses on the latent phase’s skill-building and lack of conflict; its audio-video content doesn’t directly pertain to uncovering trauma or symptom relief, so it isn’t a primary cause of the change seen in event 9.

question: In event 10, the presenter shows the slide “What traits matter? LINEAR SELECTION” with percentages and states there is linear directional selection on body shape, height, and penis size. Which earlier sub-events most directly generated the data and analysis that led to this result being computed and presented?
options: A: Event 3: Introducing 343 male humanoid figures varying in height, body shape, and penis size (95% of men in range) as the stimulus set.
B: Event 6: Asking 105 women to view full life-sized video images to elicit a visceral response, rather than using questionnaires.
C: Event 9: Applying a standard evolutionary selection analysis to the attractiveness rankings.
D: Event 1: Framing the topic with cultural magazine covers and historic context about size preoccupations.
gold_reasoning:
Result sub-event: Event 10 visually displays the “What traits matter? LINEAR SELECTION” slide with percentages (body shape 79.7%, height 6.1%, penis size 5.1). The audio in event 10 states there is linear/directional selection on these traits and emphasizes the relative importance, including that height and penis size matter.
Causal chain across events: 
- Event 3 (visual): The slide explicitly shows “343 male humanoid figures” with 7 levels each of height, body shape, and penis size, covering 95% of men. (audio): The speaker describes varying these traits across a set of male humanoid figures. These stimuli are the necessary inputs for any selection analysis on trait effects.
- Event 6 (visual): The “Data Collection” slide states that full life-sized video images were presented to 105 women. (audio): The speaker explains why life-sized videos were used to elicit visceral responses rather than relying on questionnaires. This procedure generates the attractiveness rankings that the later analysis uses.
- Event 9 (visual): The “Data Collection” slide includes “Standard evolutionary selection analysis.” (audio): The speaker explains this analysis is uncontroversial, widely used in animals, and here applied to humans. This analytic step converts the collected rankings into the linear selection estimates shown in event 10.
Why D is not causal: Event 1 provides cultural/historical framing (visual magazine covers; audio about Western preoccupation), but it does not generate data or perform analysis. Therefore, A, B, and C jointly and directly cause the result presented in event 10, as evidenced by both the visual slides and the corresponding audio explanations.

question: In event 12, the slide announces “Shorter time to rank males with small than large penis,” and the speaker explains women quickly dismissed small sizes. Which earlier sub-events most directly enabled this time-difference outcome to be detected?
options: A: Event 5: Presenting life-sized, moving figures with explicit penis size variation (5–13 cm flaccid) to enhance perceptual sensitivity to size differences.
B: Event 7: Having participants rank each video 1–7 for attractiveness with measured response times (mean ~3.1 seconds).
C: Event 3: Constructing 343 figures with seven levels of penis size (and height/body shape) to create the small-versus-large categories being compared.

gold_reasoning:
Result sub-event: Event 12 visually shows a graph with a red banner “Shorter time to rank males with small than large penis,” while the audio states that women quickly dismissed a small penis as unattractive and moved on.
Causal chain across events:
- Event 5 (visual): The slide shows “Penis size variation” and the figures are presented life-size; (audio) the speaker explains they arranged the figures to move, which subtly increases perceivability of penis size. This presentation choice makes it easier and faster for viewers to detect small versus large sizes, enabling time differences to emerge.
- Event 7 (visual): The “Data Collection” slide lists rankings from 1 to 7 and notes a “Mean of 3.1 seconds,” indicating response times were measured. (audio) The speaker emphasizes participants responded very quickly. Without timing the ranking task, the differential in event 12 could not be detected.
- Event 3 (visual): The “Video animations” slide specifies 7 levels of penis size within 343 figures. (audio) The speaker confirms these controlled variations. This stimulus design creates the small and large categories whose response times are compared in event 12.
Why D is not causal: Event 13’s heatmap shows attractiveness patterns across height and penis size (visual) with audio interpretation of contour levels, but it does not establish or measure response-time differences. Therefore, A, B, and C are the direct enablers of the time-difference result described in event 12, supported by both visuals and audio.

question: Result sub-event: In event 7 (00:06:40–00:07:41), the team secures a black strap around the patient’s waist and prepares a prone Jackknife/Kraske setup with padding, while the narration warns about restricted ventilation and other risks. gold_reasoning: The waist strap and padded, raised-frame setup in event 7 are precautionary measures tied to the Jackknife/Kraske prone modification. Establishing this causality requires both the narration and visuals across earlier segments. Event 0 (audio) frames all subsequent positioning choices by emphasizing the balance between surgical access and patient physiology, which directly motivates safety measures like secure strapping and ventilation precautions later seen/heard in event 7 (B). Event 1 (audio+vision) provides the baseline restraint practice: while the narrator explains supine alignment, the visuals show the patient already secured with black straps—standard safety protocol that is logically extended when the patient is transitioned to more demanding positions (C). Event 6 (audio) then specifically introduces prone variations and their applications to perianal regions, aligning with the jackknife indication; its visuals show meticulous positioning in the labeled “Lateral (Sims) Position,” reinforcing the broader practice of padding and alignment before prone modifications (A). These prior audio-visual cues collectively explain why, in event 7, the team both secures the waist strap and uses padding/raised supports while warning about restricted ventilation and body-part risks. Event 2 concerns Trendelenburg-related, lower-abdominal/pelvic access and shoulder-brace cautions, which are not prerequisites for the jackknife prone setup, so it does not directly cause the event 7 precautions.

Select all that apply.

B: Event 1: The tip to take pride in your notes and make them beautiful.
C: Event 1: The tip to find a consistent place to revise (e.g., a café) to help your mindset.
D: Event 2: Demonstrating and praising fast-drying Pentel EnerGel pens while creatively writing headings like “ESSAY PLANS” and drawing visuals in notes.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 3): Visually, we see a close-up of colorful, neatly organized bullet-point notes with drawings (“person,” “brain,” speech bubbles) under headings like “Understanding Consumer Needs” and “Influences.” The audio here emphasizes her preference for bullet-point essay plans over mind maps, confirming the formatting choice we visually observe. Causal chain across earlier events: (A) Event 0 visually shows a close-up of colorful pens while the audio announces the Pentel sponsorship. This both introduces and foregrounds the specific tools (pens) that enable the later colorful note style. (B) In event 1, the audio tip explicitly advises “take pride in your notes and make them beautiful,” setting a clear intention for attractive, decorated notes that aligns with the later visual outcome. (D) In event 2, the audio praises Pentel EnerGel pens (fast-drying, comfortable, high quality) and visually shows her actually writing creative headings like “ESSAY PLANS” and adding drawings (brain, speech bubble). This demonstrates the exact technique and tools that directly manifest as the colorful bullet-point notes seen in event 3. Why not (C): Although event 1 also mentions finding a consistent place to revise (café), that’s about location/mindset and does not directly cause the specific colorful, bullet-pointed and illustrated notes we see; the beauty-oriented tip and pen demonstration are the operative causes here.

question: Result sub-event: In event 7, REG_ID is highlighted/selected as the primary key, and the slide states that SID and EMAIL become alternate keys. Which earlier events set up the conditions that lead to this outcome? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 5: The CANDIDATE KEY slides and narration identifying minimal keys for the Student table (e.g., SID, REG_ID, EMAIL) and ruling out unnecessary combinations.
B: Event 6: The PRIMARY KEY slide and narration stating that a primary key is a candidate key and you can pick any one candidate key to serve as the primary key.
C: Event 8: The FOREIGN KEY slide introducing the Branch Table and discussing referential integrity between tables.
D: Event 1: The WHAT ARE DBMS KEYS? slide and narration explaining that keys uniquely identify records in a table using a simple student example.
gold_reasoning: The outcome in event 7—REG_ID chosen as the primary key and SID/EMAIL becoming alternate keys—follows a causal chain built in events 5 → 6 → 7, requiring both visuals and audio. Event 5 visually shows the Student table and lists possible keys (SID, REG_ID, EMAIL), while the audio clarifies that candidate keys are minimal superkeys and eliminates unnecessary combinations. This establishes exactly which attributes are eligible to be chosen. Event 6 then visually defines "PRIMARY KEY" (no nulls, unique, every row must have one) and includes text instructing to "Pick any one as Primary Key", while the audio explains that a primary key is a candidate key and the DBA can choose any one of the candidates. These two steps together set the rule and the eligible set. In event 7, the visual interface emphasizes REG_ID (highlighted/pointed) and the bullet points say that choosing REG_ID as the primary key makes SID and EMAIL alternate keys; the audio explains that alternate keys are the candidate keys not selected as primary. Thus, A and B are the direct prerequisites enabling the selection of REG_ID and the consequent designation of SID/EMAIL as alternate keys. C concerns foreign keys and cross-table integrity, not the primary/alternate key selection in this table. D is a general definition of keys but does not specifically identify the candidate set or the rule that the primary is chosen from candidates, so it is not a direct cause of this specific outcome.

question: Result sub-event: In event 11, Dr. Joe Dortch (checkered shirt, identified on-screen) states that the timeline for people reaching Australia has been pushed from about 50,000 to around 70,000 years. Which preceding events/sub-events most plausibly enabled and led to this revised 70,000-year timeline claim? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 4: Professor Eske Willerslev (identified on-screen) explains using an early-1920s Southwestern Australian hair sample chosen to maximize an unadmixed Aboriginal genome and notes no recent European admixture with contamination removable from the hair surface, enabling a clean genome for analysis.

B: Events 6–7: Dr. Michael Bunce (identified on-screen, beige blazer) details isolating DNA from hair shafts and using new sequencing technology to break and reassemble fragments like a huge jigsaw, allowing ancient samples to be read.

C: Event 2: Professor Eske Willerslev (black suit, on-screen ID) reports at least two early expansions and specifically that ancestors of Aboriginal Australians expanded into the world around 70,000 years ago, a conclusion drawn from the genomic evidence.
D: Event 12: A cave site’s sediments were re-dated in the 1990s using luminescence techniques at “Devil’s …”, providing an archaeological sequence.
gold_reasoning: Audio in event 11 has Dr. Joe Dortch (visually identified by the on-screen title and checkered shirt in event 10 that continues through event 11) asserting the shift of the arrival timeline toward 70,000 years. That result relies on the genomic work described earlier. In event 4, Professor Eske Willerslev (visually identified by the on-screen title and black suit) explains the hair sample’s Southwestern Australian origin, its collection in the early 1920s, selection to avoid recent European admixture, and the fact that contamination lies on the hair’s exterior—audio that directly supports obtaining a clean Aboriginal genome (visual focus on Willerslev). In events 6–7, Dr. Michael Bunce (on-screen ID, beige blazer) audibly outlines the lab methods—isolating DNA from hair shafts and using new sequencing tech to reconstruct the genome like a jigsaw—which visually and audibly shows how very old samples could be decoded. With those methods and materials in place, Willerslev in event 2 (same on-screen identification and attire) explicitly states the 70,000-year expansion of Aboriginal ancestors derived from the genome, which causally underpins Dortch’s later public framing in event 11. By contrast, event 12’s luminescence re-dating is archaeological context but not the proximate cause of the specific 70,000-year genomic inference expressed by Dortch.

question: Result sub-event: In event 15, Dr. Craig Muller (red-striped shirt, on-screen ID) says the regional board gave an “unqualified endorsement” for the research. Which preceding events/sub-events most plausibly led to that endorsement? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 13: The project’s engagement with traditional owners and focus on recovering human (and even plant/animal) DNA to understand how people arrived and where they came from, initiated in response to Aboriginal cultural concerns.
B: Event 14: Dr. Craig Muller researched and explained the 1923 provenance of the hair sample (collected by Alfred Haddon at Golden Ridge), addressing community questions about how it was obtained.
C: Event 15 (earlier sub-event): Professor Willerslev came to Australia and personally discussed the research with the board before the endorsement.

gold_reasoning: Audio in event 15 has Dr. Craig Muller (visually identified by the on-screen title and red-striped shirt) stating the board’s unqualified endorsement. This endorsement follows a chain of community-focused actions detailed across prior events. In event 13, the audio notes that the research was initiated because of Aboriginal cultural concerns, and that the team worked with traditional owners—visually shown as a transition from Dr. Joe Dortch (checkered shirt) to Dr. Muller—demonstrating engagement that would build trust. In event 14, Muller (same red-striped shirt and on-screen ID) audibly details investigating the hair sample’s 1923 collection by Alfred Haddon at Golden Ridge, directly addressing provenance and consent concerns; the visuals keep focus on Muller to tie his role to this reassurance. In event 15, before announcing the endorsement, Muller explains that Professor Willerslev came to Australia to speak with the board—an earlier sub-event within the same segment—providing face-to-face consultation. These steps collectively and causally led to the board’s endorsement. Event 11 discusses human capabilities and Australia’s isolation, which is thematically relevant but not a direct cause of the board’s decision.

question: In event 9, the speaker culminates the argument by showing examples from Arabic/Chinese and from Chaucer/Shakespeare and concludes that it “wouldn’t make sense to label it wrong.” Which earlier sub-events most directly set up and caused this conclusion to be necessary and convincing?
options: A: Event 7: The narrator says some people mistake AAVE for errors though it is a consistent language, while a diagram visually situates AAVE among other Englishes and shows influences from African languages.

B: Event 8: After detailing TH substitutions and consonant cluster simplification on a screen titled “Phonology,” the narrator explicitly notes that people notice grammar differences the most, priming a shift to grammar-focused examples.
C: Event 3: A definition of “General American English” as a professional dialect appears alongside visuals of a presidential podium, news media, and a large pink speech bubble.

D: Event 2: The narrator introduces AAVE and notes it is often mislabeled as slang or “broken English,” while visuals show big-city backdrops (Chicago, Los Angeles, New York) and reacting stick figures.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 9): The visuals show an Arabic flag and historical English texts (Canterbury Tales, Twelfth Night) while the audio argues that if those grammars existed, it doesn’t make sense to call them wrong. This conclusion is caused by earlier points that build pressure against the “errors” narrative. In event 2 (audio), the narrator states AAVE is often mislabeled as slang or “broken English”; the urban city visuals (Chicago/LA/NYC) broaden the context to nationwide usage, motivating a rebuttal. In event 7 (audio), the narrator clarifies that AAVE is a consistent system that some people mistake for errors; the diagram visually embeds AAVE within English varieties and shows African influences, directly challenging the idea of “wrongness.” Event 8’s “Phonology” section (visual title and TH-distribution map) transitions to the audio claim that people notice grammar most, setting the stage for event 9’s grammar-based cross-linguistic and historical examples. Together, the mislabeling (event 2), the correction that AAVE is consistent (event 7), and the pivot to grammar salience (event 8) causally lead to the need and logic of the event 9 conclusion. Event 3’s professional-register focus is tangential and not the primary causal setup.

question: In event 6, the animation highlights the Great Migration (1910–1970) with arrows moving north and presents AAVE as a distinct linguistic form across the U.S. map. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led to this later depiction of AAVE’s spread and distinct status?
options: A: Event 5: A map of the Atlantic with arrows shows forced transatlantic movement while the speaker explains that separated groups diverge and that enslaved Africans were brought to the Americas.
B: Event 4: The speaker explains bidialectalism and regional variation, with a U.S. map in shades of purple and a magnifying glass on AAVE–General American interactions, plus LA/NYC/Chicago figures.
C: Event 2: AAVE is introduced against collages of Chicago, Los Angeles, and New York, with stick figures’ reactions emphasizing widespread urban contexts for AAVE use.
D: Event 3: The video defines “General American English” for professional settings with imagery of a presidential podium and media outlets.
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (event 6): Visually, arrows labeled 1910–1970 move from the South to the North (Great Migration), purple markers appear across the U.S., and an evolution graphic contrasts General American and Early Modern English while introducing AAVE as distinct. The audio explicitly discusses the Great Migration and two origin theories for AAVE, saying both are likely true. This depiction is causally set up by earlier events: In event 5, the audio proposes divergence when groups stop interacting and describes the forced movement of enslaved Africans; the Atlantic arrows visually anchor this history, laying a foundation for distinct varieties forming. In event 4, the audio explains bidialectalism and regional variation (Black speakers across regions sounding more similar to each other than to local white speakers), while the U.S. map and magnifying-glass visuals highlight national distribution and interaction—direct precursors to the nationwide markers in event 6. In event 2, AAVE is first introduced; the city collages (Chicago/LA/NYC) and differing stick-figure reactions visually prefigure major urban centers tied to migration and spread. When event 6 animates the Great Migration and shows AAVE as a distinct branch and distribution, it synthesizes the historical divergence (event 5) and modern regional patterns (event 4), in line with the earlier urban context (event 2). Event 3’s professional-register discussion is not a primary driver of the migration/spread depiction.

question: Result sub-event (in event 5): The narrator explicitly challenges using written spaces to define words, asking how to distinguish “soft snow” from “softsnow,” while visuals show adjectives merging with nouns and adverbs merging with verbs, a Rubik’s cube, and earlier snow context. Which earlier moments most directly caused this conclusion by establishing that different languages can package lots of information into single words? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 1: The speaker introduces “polysynthetic,” shows the Yupik example word “angyaghllangyugtuqlu” with a citation, and explains (in audio) that some languages combine smaller words into larger words.
B: Event 0: A Venn diagram of “Word” and “Syllable,” angry stick figures, and discussion shifting topics from syllables to words.
C: Event 3: The narrator explains in audio that Spanish verb endings encode the subject so pronouns can be omitted; visuals show “Yo corro” with the ‘o’ circled and ‘Subject’ merging into ‘Verb.’
D: Event 4: The Arabic examples “أحبك” and “أحبها” (I like you / I like her) with audio stating Arabic verbs reflect both who likes and what is liked, allowing single-word sentences.
gold_reasoning: In event 5 (audio), the narrator asks how to tell “soft snow” from “softsnow” and argues that spaces are unreliable for defining words; on-screen (visual) we see adjective+noun and adverb+verb combinations, signaling morphological packaging. This conclusion is causally prepared by several prior segments: Event 1 (visual: the term “polysynthetic” and the Yupik example word; audio: explicit explanation that some languages easily combine smaller words into larger words) directly frames the idea that languages can build long, single words. Event 3 (visual: “Yo corro” with circled ‘o’ and a diagram where ‘Subject’ overlaps with ‘Verb’; audio: Spanish endings encode the subject so pronouns can be dropped) shows information being packed into a single word via inflection. Event 4 (visual: compact Arabic forms “أحبك/أحبها”; audio: verbs reflect both who likes and what is liked) demonstrates entire propositions fitting into one word. Together these lead to the event 5 challenge about word boundaries despite spaces. Event 0, while thematically adjacent (words vs syllables), does not supply the specific morphological packaging needed to motivate the “softsnow” dilemma.

question: Event 12 declares on-screen that “A Communist Revolution is inevitable,” paired with dialogue where a top-hat figure says “You can’t do that!” and the factory replies “Yes we can,” and the narrator asserts working the means of production regardless of private property. Which earlier sub-events most directly build toward this revolutionary conclusion?
options: A: Event 11: The narrator describes overproduction, unaffordable goods, falling profits, and layoffs (audio), while visuals show factories with “For Sale,” “STOP,” and “KEEP OUT” signs and people leaving or collapsed (visual), ending with “So what do we do?”

B: Event 9: The speaker states profit from workers is exploitation enabled by private property and questions whether to abolish private property (audio), supported by visuals connecting EXPLOITATION to PRIVATE PROPERTY and a choice between working for the capitalist or starving (visual).

C: Event 8: The narrator questions the fairness of “surplus value,” showing a working figure creating value while a non-working figure benefits (audio), with visuals contrasting “working” (checkmark) and “Not Working” (X) alongside “surplus value.”
D: Event 5: A definition-focused segment where exchange-value is quantifiable and money serves as a medium (audio), illustrated with potatoes, matches, and arrows indicating exchangeability (visual).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event (Event 12): Visually, the screen announces “A Communist Revolution is inevitable,” includes a dialogue where a top-hat figure says “You can’t do that!” and the factory answers “Yes we can,” and shows a diagram linking labor (hammer/books) to “Value.” Auditorily, the narrator asserts that workers might work the means of production regardless of private property and discusses a communist revolution. Preceding causal build-up spans multiple events: (1) Event 11 presents a material crisis: the audio explains overproduction, unaffordable goods, and layoffs, culminating in the prompt “So what do we do?”, while visuals depict shuttered factories with “For Sale,” “STOP,” “KEEP OUT,” and people leaving or collapsed. This crisis creates the immediate problem that a revolutionary solution purports to address. (2) Event 9 supplies the institutional critique: audio states that capitalist profit is exploitation enabled by private property and pointedly asks whether private property should be abolished. Visuals link EXPLOITATION to PRIVATE PROPERTY and show the coercive choice “keep working for capitalist” or “starve.” This frames private property as a barrier that revolution would confront, matching Event 12’s dialogue (“You can’t do that!” vs “Yes we can”). (3) Event 8 contributes the normative grievance: audio questions the fairness of surplus value when a working figure creates value while a non-working figure benefits; visuals contrast “working” (checkmark) with “Not Working” (X) alongside “surplus value.” This fairness critique provides ethical motivation for revolutionary change. Together, the crisis conditions (Event 11), structural diagnosis (Event 9), and fairness argument (Event 8), evidenced in both narration and visuals, cohere into the Event 12 conclusion that a communist revolution is the proposed outcome. Option D (Event 5) merely defines exchange value and money’s role; it does not directly motivate or necessitate revolution in the narrative.

question: Later, the video displays a formal on‑screen definition of solar energy and starts an explanation about it. Which earlier sub-events most directly led to that explanatory segment appearing? (Select all that apply)
options: A: A child earlier wonders if sunlight can be captured and stored for night use while lamenting frequent power cuts and asking about hospital equipment (event 3).
B: At night, the group notices the entire street has no power while one pole’s light is still on, and they use a torch to see (event 4).
C: Near the fallen wire, the substation uncle explains that the streetlights run on solar energy, prompting the children to ask if sunlight can actually be captured and used (event 5).
D: An elder nostalgically recalls life without fans, tube lights, TV, or radio while appliance icons are shown (event 2).
correct_answer: A child earlier wonders if sunlight can be captured and stored for night use while lamenting frequent power cuts and asking about hospital equipment (event 3).
At night, the group notices the entire street has no power while one pole’s light is still on, and they use a torch to see (event 4).
Near the fallen wire, the substation uncle explains that the streetlights run on solar energy, prompting the children to ask if sunlight can actually be captured and used (event 5).
gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: the explicit on-screen definition and explanation of solar energy appears at the start of event 6 (visual text defining solar energy; audio begins emphasizing solar energy derived from the sun). The causes span prior events and require both modalities. In event 3 (audio), a child asks about capturing and storing sunlight for nighttime use after observing electricity use in cities; visually, thought bubbles (kitchen, X-ray machine) contextualize electric usage. In event 4, the visual shows the children outside at night with a torch, and the audio notes, “there is no power in the entire street,” yet “the pole at the crossroads has a light on,” creating the puzzle to be explained. In event 5, visuals include the nighttime scene with workers and an adult near electrical equipment; the audio has the substation uncle explicitly say those streetlights run on solar energy, with the children asking if sunlight can be captured. This sequence of curiosity (event 3), puzzling observation (event 4), and explicit causal explanation (event 5) directly precipitates the formalized teaching segment on solar energy in event 6. Event 2’s nostalgic recollection is thematic background about electricity, not a direct cause for the solar-energy explanation.

question: By the end, the video issues a strong safety warning on screen about fallen electrical wires and staying away from poles. Which earlier sub-events most directly contributed to this final safety caution? (Select all that apply)

The contributing causes appear across events and require both audio and visuals. In event 7, visuals include a hazard sign (electrocution symbol) and the girl holding a sign with a red cross over touching sockets, while the audio explains heavy wind can make wires fall and people may be electrocuted—broadening the safety rationale. In event 10, the visual shows birds on live wires; the audio emphasizes concern that birds can be electrocuted and sometimes cause power cuts, reinforcing the hazards of live lines. These threads culminate in event 11’s consolidated safety warning. Event 8’s heating-effect demonstration is educational but unrelated to the wire/pole safety caution.

question: In event 9, the hand underlines the final magnetic bearing “117° 01'” while the speaker says “117 degrees, zero one minute” and notes that magnetic bearing does not include direction. Which earlier sub-events most directly enabled this final result?

In event 8 (visual: the equation “magnetic bearing = True bearing + magnetic declination” and the written/entered “94° + 23° 01'” with a calculator; audio: the formula and calculation are explained), the speaker combines these inputs, setting up the exact sum that yields the final 117° 01' seen and spoken in event 9. Event 5, although related to orientation, does not directly supply the numerical inputs or the explicit calculation that produce the final magnetic bearing, so it is not a primary cause of the result.

question: In event 7, after goats appear around the three pink-headed figures, the figures collapse to the ground with X’s over their eyes. Which earlier sequences most directly set up the dynamics that lead to this collapse (i.e., why widespread stealing makes everyone worse off)? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 4 — The narrator frames good as helping the group and evil as harming it and cites the prisoner’s dilemma, while visuals show a lineup of figures reacting to harm and later holding leafy/flowered sticks to illustrate cooperative versus harmful outcomes.
B: Event 5 — The humorous arrest scenario (two cosmic figures) where the narrator lays out confession versus silence outcomes, modeling the incentives in a prisoner’s dilemma.
C: Event 6 — The highlighted network of green and purple nodes as the narrator contrasts betrayal and cooperation, emphasizing selfish motives and how individual choices affect overall outcomes.

gold_reasoning: Result sub-event: In event 7, the visuals show goats appearing and then the three pink-headed figures falling with X’s over their eyes; the audio narrates a clan analogy, explaining that if everyone steals goats, stealing becomes pointless and identifies this as the basic problem of human group behavior. The collapse signifies the worst-case payoff when defection is widespread. The causal chain is established in earlier events through both narration and diagrams: (A) Event 4 introduces the prisoner’s dilemma conceptually: the audio says good helps the group and evil harms it, explicitly referencing the prisoner’s dilemma; visually, the figures’ reactions to harm (flame, pile of sticks) versus later calm with leafy/flowered sticks illustrate how non-cooperation degrades group welfare—laying the conceptual groundwork for why universal stealing is disastrous. (B) Event 5 concretizes the dilemma with a stylized case (two cosmic figures) in which the narrator details confession versus non-confession outcomes—an audio walk-through of defection/cooperation incentives—while visuals show the pair and an outcome diagram, mapping individual choices to group payoffs. (C) Event 6 continues the same theme with a network of nodes highlighted while the audio contrasts betrayal with cooperation and explains selfish motivations; visually, the focused nodes in the network underscore how individual decisions propagate through a system and degrade collective outcomes when many defect. These three prior explanations directly set up the event 7 outcome: when the goat clan universally defects (steals), everyone’s position worsens, depicted by the figures’ collapse. (D) In contrast, event 8 presents an evolutionary countermeasure—the “nigila” punishes theft and rewards sharing—meant to reduce stealing; this would mitigate, not cause, the collapse, so it is not a direct contributor to the observed result.

question: After the narrator says Romans were “masters of the arch and the dome,” we see a Roman-style building with arches and a dome being drawn (result sub-event in event 7). Which earlier sub-events most directly set up why Romans would develop and showcase such monumental architecture?

First, event 5 (audio) states Romans admired Greek culture and copied Greek architecture, providing the cultural and technical foundation for Roman building practices; the visuals of dual-labeled gods (e.g., Zeus/Jupiter) reinforce their systematic adoption of Greek models. Second, event 6 (audio) explains Romans used art for propaganda and cites Trajan’s Column as a cinematic record of victories; visuals of scaffolding/workers around a monument emphasize active monumental production. These two causes—adopting Greek architectural ideas (event 5) and deploying monuments for imperial messaging (event 6)—together explain why, by event 7, we hear about mastery of arches and domes and see such architecture drawn. Event 3’s Greek Golden Age content and event 1’s pottery discussion provide context for earlier Greek art but do not directly cause Roman monumental architecture to be featured here.

question: In event 16, Derek Corrigan declares he would even put his body in front of a bulldozer to stop the project. Which earlier factors most directly drove him to this extreme stance?

question: In event 4, the interviewee reports that he received 350,000 votes and became the most voted candidate in his state. Which earlier sub-events most directly set up that outcome? Select all that apply.

question: Result sub-event (Event 5): The IAEA chief says they went to Tokyo to speak with the Prime Minister, requested facilitation and “the highest level of transparency,” and that the flow of information later improved. Event 7 is about pre-disaster prevention (not about immediate info flow) and occurs later, and Event 1’s activist measurements, while alarming, are not the direct on-air interrogation that led the IAEA to push Japan for better data. Thus A and B are the primary contributing factors evidenced by both the visuals (live interview context and crisis banners) and the audio (pointed questions about timeliness and honesty).

options: A: Event 6: The speaker recounts a driver who was hit by another rideshare driver and then couldn’t work, facing medical bills through no fault of their own (on-screen text asks why AB5 is necessary to protect drivers).

B: Event 7: The speaker highlights that drivers are potentially missing out on workers’ compensation and unemployment insurance, noting California has rules (paired with on-screen prompt about AB5 protecting drivers).

C: Event 3: The speaker explains AB5’s legal test (from a Supreme Court decision) that clarifies who is an employee based on doing the employer’s primary work, applied broadly for classification clarity (on-screen text: What Is AB5?).
D: Event 1: The host mentions covering AB5 rallies in Sacramento and that drivers are confused about the bill, with visuals of rally signs like “I’M INDEPENDENT!”
gold_reasoning: Audio in event 10 enumerates workers’ compensation and unemployment insurance as key benefits if the bill passes, while the on-screen text visually frames this as “What happens next for drivers?” The need to stress these protections is causally grounded by multiple earlier sub-events. In event 6 (audio), the speaker details a crash victim driver who loses work and faces medical bills; visually, the prompt “Why is AB5 necessary to protect drivers?” signals the segment’s purpose, directly motivating workers’ compensation. In event 7 (audio), she explicitly says drivers are missing workers’ comp and unemployment insurance; the same on-screen prompt visually reinforces that gap, making these benefits salient. In event 3 (audio), she lays out AB5’s employee-classification test and its broad application; visually, “What Is AB5?” frames this as the legal mechanism enabling access to those protections. Together, the harm case (event 6), the identified missing benefits (event 7), and the legal reclassification mechanism (event 3) causally lead to the event 10 result: emphasizing workers’ comp and unemployment insurance. Event 1, although contextually related (rallies and confusion), does not directly establish the need for these specific protections nor the legal pathway, so it is not a primary cause.

question: In event 7, the result sub-event is the speaker recounting that mayors said the Mayor's Institute "changed their thinking" about their cities. Which preceding sub-events most directly caused this outcome? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 5 — The speaker explains the purpose of the Mayor's Institute for City Design: mayors wield strong design power yet lack formal training, and the built environment is their legacy.

B: Event 6 — The speaker describes immersing city leaders in urban design principles, saying it leads to "more handsome, more sustainable, more beautiful, more inspirational" cities and that it "has worked every time."
C: Event 0 — Opening argument that politicians must understand the built environment because most people now live in metropolitan areas and politicians shape those environments.
D: Event 4 — The speaker argues for affordable housing to avoid displacement as areas gentrify.
gold_reasoning: The causal chain spans events 5 → 6 → 7. Visually, event 5 is introduced by the black title card “What is the Mayor's Institute for City Design?” and then returns to the same formal setting with the older man in front of the portrait, flag, and bust, signaling a focused segment about the Institute. In the audio of event 5, he states that mayors have enormous power over city design, often lack specific training, and that the built environment is their legacy—this sets up why the Institute exists and how it targets mayors (cause). In event 6, in the same visual setting, he intensifies the point: the audio explains that immersing city leaders in urban design leads to better, more inspirational outcomes and “has worked every time,” indicating the mechanism by which the Institute changes thinking (proximate cause). Event 7 then provides the result sub-event: in the audio he says mayors report the program changed their thinking, and visually this segment closes with the arbuckle industries logo card—marking the culmination of the argument. Options C and D are not direct causes of the reported change: C is a broad opening premise about politicians and the built environment (context, not the specific intervention), and D concerns affordable housing policy generally, not the Institute’s pedagogy that triggered the mayors’ mindset shift.

question: In event 3, the result sub-event is the speaker pivoting to define elements of a "livable city"—ownership and inclusion for residents, child-friendly neighborhoods, and beautiful public realms. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led to this emphasis? Choose all that apply.
options: A: Event 1 — The speaker urges that projects like transportation and road construction consider everyone, noting past oversights of bicycles, pedestrians, and neighborhood connectedness.

B: Event 2 — The speaker reflects that public works have compromised aesthetic and community considerations, arguing political decisions should pass through a filter of thoughtful planning and design.
C: Event 0 — The speaker asserts politicians must understand the built environment since people live in metropolitan areas and politicians shape those environments.
D: Event 5 — Introduction to the Mayor’s Institute for City Design, emphasizing mayors’ power and lack of design training.
gold_reasoning: The causal relationship threads through events 1 → 2 → 3. Visually, event 3 is framed by the title card “What are the elements of a livable city?”, signaling a new focus before returning to the same formal room with the speaker. In the audio of event 3, he lists inclusion, child-friendly neighborhoods, and beautiful public realms—this is the result sub-event (the articulated emphasis). That emphasis is driven by earlier causes: In event 1, the audio highlights previous failures to account for cyclists, pedestrians, and neighborhood connectedness in transportation and road projects—implicitly motivating a people-first lens. In event 2, still in the same setting, the audio laments how aesthetics and community impact have been compromised and prescribes a “filter of thoughtful planning and design,” which logically leads to specifying livability criteria in event 3. Option C (event 0) is background framing about politicians and the built environment but not the immediate antecedent for the pivot to specific livability elements, and option D (event 5) occurs later in time and centers on the Mayor’s Institute, not on defining livability, so it cannot plausibly be the cause of event 3’s emphasis.

question: In Event 8, Michael Moore advocates on-air for a tiny financial transaction tax ("a half a penny or a quarter of a penny per dollar") and says it could raise about $350 billion a year. Which earlier segments most directly set up and catalyzed this specific on-air advocacy by pre-framing the idea and showing growing support for such a tax?
options: A: Event 3: A segment from the G20 in France where a speaker explains Bill Gates urging a financial transaction tax and describes it as a very small levy (around a quarter of a percent) on trades.
B: Event 4: Coverage of National Nurses United marching in Washington for a financial transaction tax and news that Senators Harkin and DeFazio introduced a bill to reinstate it.
C: Event 0: Warren Buffett discusses his personal tax rate (17.7%) vs. his office average (32.9%), noting he simply follows Congress’s rules.
D: Event 5: Report that religious and political leaders (e.g., the Archbishop of Canterbury, a Catholic Church statement, Merkel, Sarkozy) are voicing support for such an idea.
gold_reasoning: To see why Moore pushes the financial transaction tax in Event 8, we must synthesize both what was said and what was shown in multiple earlier segments. In Event 3, audio explicitly introduces the financial transaction tax and quantifies it as a small levy (“around a quarter of a percent”), while the visuals place the discussion at the G20 (e.g., signage like “G20 FRANCE 2011” and podium shots), signaling global policy relevance. Event 4’s audio reports nurses marching in Washington for the tax and that Harkin/DeFazio introduced a bill, while the visuals show a large red-shirted crowd and a banner reading “Tax Wall Street,” evidencing organized domestic momentum. Event 5’s audio lists high-profile backers—including religious leaders and European heads of state—while the visuals cut to ecclesiastical and political figures, underscoring breadth of support. With this multi-source framing and visible public and elite backing, Moore’s on-air push in Event 8—seen visually in the bookstore interview frame and heard as he specifies “a half a penny per dollar” and “$350 billion a year”—flows as a natural escalation. By contrast, Event 0’s Warren Buffett tax-rate anecdote (shown in a formal interview shot and heard as a personal rate comparison) highlights inequality generally but does not directly pre-frame the specific FTT proposal that Moore advances.

question: In Event 10, the host presses about how specific the Occupy protesters’ demands are. Which prior moments most plausibly prompted this particular line of questioning?
options: A: Event 9: The host states she wants to talk to Michael because he has been visiting occupied protests and thinks strategically about how America changes.
B: Event 6: The anchor wraps a rundown of international support for bank fees/taxes by asking whether the idea seems doable, pushing the conversation toward concrete policy.
C: Event 8: Michael Moore lays out a concrete revenue idea—“half a penny per dollar” on stock trades yielding “$350 billion a year”—setting up a discussion about specific demands.
D: Event 1: The report that many Fortune 500 companies paid little or no federal income tax while ordinary people paid more.
gold_reasoning: The host’s Event 10 question about the specificity of Occupy’s demands is cued by a chain of earlier audio and visual signals steering the segment toward concrete asks. In Event 9, the audio is explicit: the host explains she wants to talk to Michael because he’s been visiting occupied protests and thinks strategically about change—visually paired with the studio-to-bookstore interview setup—directly motivating a focus on protester demands. In Event 6, the audio synthesizes widespread support (Pope, nurses, Gates, Merkel), ending with a question implying feasibility (“seems doable?”), while visuals of G20 signage, podiums, and the studio monologue indicate a pivot toward actionable policy. Event 8 then provides a specific example: Moore, seen in the bookstore interview frame, audibly details “half a penny per dollar” on trades and “$350 billion a year,” modeling the kind of concrete demand the host probes in Event 10. Event 1’s corporate tax-dodger report (visual document graphics and critical narration) establishes context about tax disparities but does not directly trigger the host’s targeted question about Occupy’s specificity.

question: Result sub-event: In event 12, the candidate intensifies his critique by condemning mandates, asserting Republicans aren’t much better, saying Santorum funded Planned Parenthood, and calling him a “fake conservative.” Which earlier exchanges most directly set up and led to this outcome?
options: A: Event 9: The interviewer asks about Rush Limbaugh’s apology and whether campaigns wandering into social issues bothers him, initiating the social/mandate topic (split-screen visuals with Campaign 2012 banner).

B: Event 10: The candidate replies that someone should have apologized due to advertisers pulling out, then pivots to Santorum’s views on birth control and mentions his own OB background (close-up against red curtains).

C: Event 11: He reframes it as a philosophical/political issue about whether government can mandate insurance coverage like free birth control, questioning the fairness of forcing others to pay (same red-curtain setting).
D: Event 6: Earlier, he expresses frustration with politicians seeking power and praises focusing on real issues, but not yet addressing the Limbaugh/Santorum/mandate thread.
gold_reasoning: Audio in event 9 launches the social-issue thread: the interviewer asks about Limbaugh’s apology and whether such social topics bother him. Visually, the split-screen with Face the Nation/Campaign 2012 confirms an interviewer–candidate exchange setting this new topic. In event 10, the close-up of the same candidate (red tie, red-curtain backdrop) continues the same segment, and the audio pivots from the apology/advertisers to Santorum’s positions and the speaker’s OB background—directly narrowing the discussion to the actors he later criticizes. Event 11, in the same visual setting (red curtains, Face the Nation bug), escalates the argument by framing it as a mandate/philosophy issue in the audio, questioning government’s authority and the fairness of forced payments. These steps naturally culminate in event 12, where the same on-camera speaker (visual continuity) delivers the strongest condemnation—calling Santorum a “fake conservative” and broadening critique of mandates. Thus, A, B, and C are the primary causal setup; D is thematically related earlier but does not initiate nor build the specific Limbaugh–mandate–Santorum chain that yields the result in event 12.

question: Result sub-event: At the start of event 9, the anchor says, “Alright, I’m going to move on here,” and reframes that the criticisms at issue are coming from African Americans within the GOP, naming Senator Tim Scott and Congressman John James. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led to this on-air pivot?
options: A: Event 5 – The anchor raises Florida’s educational standards controversy and quotes DeSantis’s standard and Tim Scott’s response that there is no silver lining in slavery.
B: Event 6 – A field clip features a man emphasizing the suffering caused by slavery, and the anchor pointedly asks, “Are you with Governor Ron DeSantis or Senator Tim Scott on this issue?”
C: Event 7 – The candidate declines to pick a side, says he stands on the side of truth, wants to teach the awful legacy of slavery, and expresses distrust of media portrayals of the curriculum.

D: Event 8 – The candidate reframes the debate as a deeper problem of teaching kids they are oppressed (“psychological slavery”) and pivots to broader priorities like the economy and national self-confidence.
gold_reasoning: The pivot in event 9 occurs immediately after an extended back-and-forth on Florida’s teaching standards. Audio in event 5 introduces the controversy (DeSantis standard and Tim Scott’s “no silver lining” quote), and event 6 adds a clip about slavery’s suffering followed by the anchor’s direct question, visually and aurally keeping the topic on that dispute. The candidate’s responses in event 7 (audio: refusing to take sides, asserting he stands with truth and on teaching the awful legacy; visual: active gestures under the “State of the Union” branding) and in event 8 (audio: reframing to “psychological slavery” and pivoting to the economy/self-confidence; visual: continued split-screen with the on-screen topic about Tim Scott and DeSantis) show him not engaging in the binary choice the anchor posed. That prolonged deflection and issue reframing set up the anchor’s decision in event 9 to move on and contextualize that the criticisms were coming from Black Republicans (Tim Scott, John James). While events 5 and 6 initiated the line of questioning, the immediate and primary causes for the pivot were the candidate’s non-committal and reframing answers in events 7 and 8, prompting the anchor to reset and proceed.

question: Result sub-event: In event 8, a Guardian news page is shown on-screen with the headline about Corbyn and May making their last pitch for votes. Which earlier sub-events most directly set up this specific on-screen Guardian headline to appear? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 4: The interviewer explicitly asks for some "clairvoyance," prompting predictions about what will happen.
B: Event 5: The interviewer asks for newspaper headline predictions for The Sun, the Daily Mail, and The Guardian.
C: Event 7: A speaker frames "the Guardian" as a liberal (not socialist) newspaper, directly introducing discussion about that outlet.

gold_reasoning: To explain why the Guardian headline appears in event 8, we need both audio and visual cues across multiple earlier events. Audio in event 4 introduces a request for "clairvoyance," priming a predictions segment. In event 5, the interviewer specifically asks for newspaper headline predictions and explicitly names The Sun, The Daily Mail, and The Guardian, setting the expectation that these outlets’ headlines will be discussed or shown. Then, in event 7, the audio zeroes in on the Guardian—describing it as a liberal, not socialist, paper—directly teeing up that outlet for focus. This Guardian-specific framing is immediately followed by the visual in event 8: the on-screen display of a Guardian headline (“Corbyn and May make last pitch for votes...”). The visual evidence in event 8 confirms that the discussion has moved to the Guardian, aligning with the audio setup from events 4, 5, and 7. By contrast, event 6’s visuals and audio concern The Sun and The Daily Mail, not the Guardian. While event 6 establishes the pattern of showing tabloid headlines, it does not directly cause the Guardian headline to appear; the Guardian-specific cue comes from event 7, which is why A, B, and C are the primary contributors.

question: Result sub-event: In event 11, the speaker urges young people to vote to prove "older Tories" wrong about youth apathy. Which earlier sub-events most directly prime and motivate this targeted appeal to young voters? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 1: The discussion highlights a huge, young and diverse army on the ground, suggesting many have felt the sharp end of policy and are mobilized.

This result sub-event is causally built on earlier multi-modal evidence: In event 1, audio emphasizes a young, diverse ground campaign, while visuals show casual outdoor canvassing and interactions in residential areas—supporting the claim of youth presence on the streets. In event 2, audio reinforces the existence of a "huge army" that includes many first-time volunteers in their twenties, and visuals again depict groups with pamphlets, underscoring active participation and the need to sustain momentum despite burnout. Event 10 escalates the mobilization message in audio by urging listeners to "drag" people to polling stations and specifically highlighting strong support from younger voters, directly prefiguring a targeted youth appeal. Together, these events create the context and urgency that lead to the focused plea in event 11. Event 6, concerned with satirical tabloid predictions and on-screen headlines, is thematically unrelated to voter mobilization and does not causally prime the youth-targeted call in event 11.

question: In event 11, the interviewee says he aims to bring a serious tone but also be lighthearted—known for telling jokes—to put parties at ease in what can be a scary courtroom. Which earlier sub-events most plausibly led him to frame and deliver this temperament explanation?

Visually, the same figure is shown in close-up with a professional studio backdrop; auditorily, he articulates impartiality, respect, and fair treatment for all—principles consistent with wanting people to feel comfortable and respected. (3) Event 9 supplies operational context. On video, he speaks emphatically with hand gestures about moving cases; on audio, he cites a heavy flow of divorces/custody cases and the need to streamline, implying the courtroom can be tense and high-pressure—conditions where a balance of seriousness and levity helps. The interplay of visuals (who asks the question, the continuity of the speaker and setting) and audio (the explicit temperament question in event 10, the fairness ethos in event 6, and the high-volume caseload in event 9) jointly supports why he answers about being serious yet lighthearted in event 11. question: Result sub-event: In event 11, the candidate explicitly lists her top three priorities as schools, affordable housing, and the opioid crisis. Which preceding sub-events most plausibly caused her to consolidate and present this list? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 10: The interviewer asks if there are any other issues or topics not covered that should be revisited, prompting a summarizing response.

By contrast, event 6 focuses on the comprehensive plan and seniors rather than the three issues she lists, so it is not a primary driver of the specific top-three summary in event 11.

question: In event 12, the interviewer pointedly asks whether there are “hundreds or thousands” of Russian trolls spreading fake news on social media. Which prior exchanges most directly set up this question? Select all that apply.
options: A: Event 9 — The interviewer raises Western concerns about increased aggression and specifically cites alleged interference in the U.S. election (e.g., DNC hacking), prompting the woman to demand specifics.
B: Event 10 — The interviewer cites Robert Mueller’s 37-page indictment naming 13 Russians, while the woman dismisses it as “just names,” pushing for concrete actions and evidence.
C: Event 11 — The interviewer describes meeting a young woman at the Internet Research Agency who spread fake news, provoking the woman to react strongly and ask for the name, treating it as a crime.
D: Event 4 — A discussion about possible U.S. airstrikes in Syria and Russia protecting its people on the ground, accompanied by somber music.
gold_reasoning: The question in event 12 about large numbers of trolls is causally built through a sequence of claims and disputes. In event 9 (audio), the interviewer brings up interference in the U.S. election and the DNC hack; visually, both speakers use animated gestures as the woman demands step-by-step specifics, keeping the focus on information operations. Event 10 (audio) escalates with the Mueller indictment naming 13 Russians; visually, the exchange grows more pointed as the woman rejects it as “just names,” insisting on concrete deeds, which motivates the interviewer to refine and intensify his line of inquiry. Event 11 (audio) then introduces a firsthand account about a worker at the Internet Research Agency spreading fake news; the woman’s shocked reaction and demand for a name (with emphatic gestures) further centers the dialogue on organized online propaganda. This escalating chain directly produces the event 12 question about “hundreds or thousands” of trolls on social platforms. Event 4, while serious, concerns potential military confrontation in Syria and does not feed into the specific social-media–troll line of questioning.

question: Result sub-event: In event 16, the official explicitly reassures that Turkey seeks good relations with all and that ties with Russia/China/the Islamic world are not alternatives to EU/Western relations. B: Event 14: The official says countries that advised normalization with Russia after an incident are now disappointed, calling it “funny, strange.”

gold_reasoning: Audio in event 13 explicitly frames the Western concern—an interviewer says Turkey–Russia relations have strengthened, some in the West feel insecure and see a zero-sum shift, and asks for a message. Visually, this is shown as a split interview sequence with two suited speakers under the TRT WORLD/One on One overlays, establishing a direct Q→A setup. Event 15’s audio further clarifies there was no anti-West message—relations with Russia were strong even before the downed aircraft and “it’s not a game”; the consistent visuals (the same official, Turkish flag, formal office) tie this explanation to the ongoing answer. These three pieces together causally lead to the result sub-event in event 16: the official’s policy reassurance that ties with Russia/China/the Islamic world are not alternatives to EU/Western relations and that Turkey aims for good relations with all; visuals in 16 again show the same setting, reinforcing continuity. Option D (event 9) is a plausible context about Europe but does not directly respond to the West’s zero-sum concern over Russia ties; it’s a broader complaint and not the immediate causal lead-in to the policy reassurance in event 16.

These lead causally to event 3, where the official responds that there’s no problem, that Russia cares about humanitarian consequences, and crucially that they will share advice/information regarding civilians around Aleppo; the visuals again show the same official setting with the Turkish flag and TRT overlays, confirming continuity and that this is the responsive action.
